question_text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain with urination and vaginal itching. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and vaginal mucosa, punctate hemorrhages on the cervix, and green-yellow, malodorous discharge. A photomicrograph of the discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of pain with urination and vaginal itching. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and vaginal mucosa, punctate hemorrhages on the cervix, and green-yellow, malodorous discharge. A photomicrograph of the discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: Microscopic examination of a wet mount preparation of this patient's vaginal discharge shows extracellular, motile, flagellated protozoa.
learning_objective: Recognize trichomoniasis, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection manifests with dysuria and vaginal discharge, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, vaginal discharge in patients with Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is typically mucopurulent (milky white), not green-yellow. Although Neisseria gonorrhoeae can cause cervicitis, it does not result in punctate cervical hemorrhages. Also, microscopic examination of vaginal discharge would not show extracellular, flagellated protozoa, since Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a facultative intracellular bacterium.

images.title: Neisseria gonorrhoeae
images.description: Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

answers.explanation_why: Treponema pallidum infection causes syphilis, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, primary syphilis causes painless chancres and nontender lymphadenopathy, not vaginal discharge, dysuria, and pruritus. In addition, microscopic examination (of serous fluid from a chancre on dark-field microscopy) shows spirochetes.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection manifests with dysuria and vaginal discharge, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, vaginal discharge in patients with Chlamydia trachomatis infection is typically mucopurulent (milky white), not green-yellow. Although Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis, it does not usually result in punctate cervical hemorrhages. Also, microscopic examination of vaginal discharge would not show extracellular organisms since Chlamydia is an intracellular organism.

images.title: Chlamydia trachomatis in McCoy cell culture (magnified view)
images.description: Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (200x magnification)The cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (example circled in blue) are identifiable by inclusion bodies (brown; example marked by hatched overlay), surrounded by a thin rim of host cytoplasm. Over the course of the pathogen's life cycle, elementary bodies (examples circled in white) are formed within the inclusion bodies. These are released from the cell and serve to transmit the pathogen to other cells or hosts.

answers.explanation_why: Gardnerella vaginalis infection manifests with vaginal discharge, and risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use. However, pruritus and pain are uncommon, and vaginal discharge in patients with bacterial vaginosis is usually gray or milky with a fishy odor. This organism does not typically cause cervical pathology. In addition, microscopic examination in patients with bacterial vaginosis shows clue cells, not motile organisms.

images.title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Candida albicans infection (vulvovaginal candidiasis) manifests with vaginal discharge, pruritus, and dysuria. However, vaginal discharge in patients with vulvovaginal candidiasis is typically odorless and appears white and curdy with a cottage cheese-like appearance. In addition, microscopic examination shows pseudohyphae, not motile organisms.

images.title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
images.description: Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.White circles: examples of budding yeast

answers.explanation_why:
Trichomonas vaginalis infection causes trichomoniasis, which manifests with vaginal pruritus, dysuria, strawberry cervix (punctate hemorrhages on the cervix), and green-yellow, malodorous vaginal discharge as seen in this patient. The presence of motile trophozoites on wet mount preparation confirms the diagnosis. Vaginal discharge typically has a pH > 4.5. Risk factors for infection include multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use.

First-line therapy for trichomoniasis is metronidazole for both the patient and the patient's partner(s).

images.title: Trichomonas vaginalis
images.description: Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-day history of low-grade fever and progressive painful lumps in his right groin. The lumps have been discharging purulent fluid since the evening of the previous day. He had a shallow, painless lesion on his penis 3 weeks ago, but was too embarrassed to seek medical attention; it has resolved in the meantime. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Examination of his groin shows multiple masses with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-day history of low-grade fever and progressive painful lumps in his right groin. The lumps have been discharging purulent fluid since the evening of the previous day. He had a shallow, painless lesion on his penis 3 weeks ago, but was too embarrassed to seek medical attention; it has resolved in the meantime. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Examination of his groin shows multiple masses with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: The history of a painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–4 weeks after the initial lesion has healed is in keeping with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).
learning_objective: Recognize lymphogranuloma venereum, and recall its causal pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus ducreyi causes the STI chancroid, which also presents with painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, single or multiple, painful genital ulcers covered with yellowish-greyish exudate would also be seen. Systemic manifestations such as fever are uncommon.

images.title: Chancroid lesion on the penis
images.description: There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

answers.explanation_why: Treponema pallidum causes the STI syphilis. Patients with primary syphilis also present with a painless, genital ulcer, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. The inguinal lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis differs in a number of ways, though: it is nonsuppurative, occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance, and is not accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). Moreover, the genital ulcer usually does not resolve within a week, but within 3–6 weeks without treatment.

images.title: Chancre of the glans penis in primary syphilis
images.description: A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Yersinia pestis is transmitted by fleas of small mammals (e.g., prairie dogs, squirrels, rats) and causes the plague, which may also present with tender, suppurative, regional lymphadenopathy (buboes) in the vicinity of the bite site (which is usually the leg), and high fever. However, bubonic plague is an extremely rare infection in the US, with an average of fewer than 7 cases reported annually. Also, patients do not present with genital ulcers.

Herpes simplex virus 2 may also cause genital ulcers, fever, and tender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, usually multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers are present and inguinal lymphadenopathy is nonsuppurative.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why: Klebsiella granulomatis causes the STI granuloma inguinale, which may also present with painless lesions on the genitals initially. However, these lesions do not resolve spontaneously without treatment, as did the painless lesion on this patient's penis. Granuloma inguinale lesions are typically beefy-red, suppurative, bleed easily (due to their hypervascularity), and spread and destroy surrounding tissue until treated. Regional lymphadenopathy and fever are generally absent, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infectionMultiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

answers.explanation_why: The serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis are responsible for LGV, which is a sexually transmitted disease with an increasing incidence among men who have sex with men. Systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, chills, and/or myalgia can occur in addition to the local symptoms in the genital region. LGV is treated with doxycycline or macrolides such as erythromycin. Without antibiotic treatment, LGV can lead to chronic genital lymphedema, strictures in the anogenital tract, and infertility.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum
images.description: Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of yellow vaginal discharge, itching, and pain with urination for the past 6 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently; she has been taking an oral contraceptive for the past 2 years. She has no history of serious illness or sexually transmitted diseases. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vagina and cervix with well-defined punctate hemorrhages and foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.8. Bimanual examination is unremarkable. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of yellow vaginal discharge, itching, and pain with urination for the past 6 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently; she has been taking an oral contraceptive for the past 2 years. She has no history of serious illness or sexually transmitted diseases. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vagina and cervix with well-defined punctate hemorrhages and foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.8. Bimanual examination is unremarkable. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Vaginal and cervical erythema with punctate hemorrhages (strawberry cervix) along with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with an elevated pH value is consistent with trichomoniasis.
learning_objective: Recognize trichomoniasis, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common cause of sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. Infection with chlamydia is often asymptomatic. If symptoms appear, they typically include (muco)purulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding. Furthermore, physical examination of the cervix often causes bleeding, whereas the bimanual examination of this patient was unremarkable.

Gram-negative diplococci indicate infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonorrhea). The disease is transmitted sexually and is usually asymptomatic in women. If symptoms arise, they typically include purulent, creamy vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding but no erythema.

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface; these cells are characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. The vaginal discharge in bacterial vaginosis also has pH > 4.5. Unlike in this patient, bacterial vaginosis usually manifests without vulvovaginal erythema and the discharge is white or grey-colored and has a fishy odor.

images.title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Pseudohyphae are loosely filamentous forms of fungi assumed by many yeasts, particularly Candida albicans, during growth. They are commonly seen on wet mounts of patients with vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis), which are associated with odorless, white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge that may resemble cottage cheese. Pregnancy, antibiotic use, and immunosuppression are predisposing factors for vaginal thrush. Even though this patient had a course of amoxicillin, her discharge is foul-smelling and yellow-green, making a candidal infection very unlikely. Also, vaginal pH is typically normal (4–4.5) in vulvovaginal candidiasis.

images.title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
images.description: Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.White circles: examples of budding yeast

answers.explanation_why:
Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile protozoan with multiple flagella. Patients typically have foul-smelling, frothy, purulent vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Transmission of this disease occurs through unprotected sex. Most patients remain asymptomatic. Treatment consists of oral metronidazole or tinidazole for the patient and sexual partner(s).

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of vaginal discharge. She has no pain or pruritus. Menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. She had a normal Pap smear 3 months ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows malodorous, gray vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.0. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of vaginal discharge. She has no pain or pruritus. Menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. She had a normal Pap smear 3 months ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows malodorous, gray vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.0. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: Malodorous, gray vaginal discharge, an increased vaginal pH, and clue cells on microscopy are consistent with bacterial vaginosis.
learning_objective: Recognize bacterial vaginosis, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Escherichia coli is a cause of vaginitis, specifically aerobic vaginitis. E. coli vaginitis is characterized by vaginal discharge and an increase in the vaginal pH (> 4.5). However, discharge caused by E. coli is usually odorless, yellowish, and manifests with pruritus.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea. Gonorrhea also manifests with vaginal discharge, but the discharge is typically odorless, purulent, and creamy. The patient is also lacking symptoms of dysuria, dyspareunia, and intermenstrual bleeding, which are typical accompanying features.

Gardnerella vaginalis is an anaerobic bacterium that causes bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is usually asymptomatic, but may manifest with gray, malodorous vaginal discharge. There are two characteristic diagnostic findings of BV: clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria) seen on a wet mount preparation and a positive amine test (sometimes referred to as the “whiff test”). The amine test consists of applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with vaginal discharge, and is positive if this causes a fishy or amine odor.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common sexually transmitted infections in the US and a common cause of female infertility. C. trachomatis infection is often asymptomatic, but if discharge occurs, it is usually odorless and purulent. Clue cells are not associated with C. trachomatis, and instead it is usually diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification tests.

Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Even though C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically odorless, white, and crumbly, and the vaginal pH would be normal (< 4.5). Additional symptoms of infection with C. albicans include intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide.

images.title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
images.description: Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.White circles: examples of budding yeast

answers.explanation_why: Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite and one of the etiologic agents of vulvovaginitis. Although T. vaginalis would cause malodorous vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5, the discharge is usually yellow-green and frothy. Additionally, vulvovaginitis due to T. vaginalis manifests with pruritus, and the microscopic examination of the discharge would instead show flagellated protozoa.

images.title: Trichomonas vaginalis
images.description: Photomicrograph of trichomonas vaginalis trophozoites (Giemsa stain; high magnification)The protozoan appears oval-shaped with flagella (examples indicated by arrowheads) and a nucleus (green overlay) located at the anterior end.

images.title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of growths around her anus that developed over the past 4 weeks. They are not painful and she does not have blood in her stool. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows nontender, irregular, hyperkeratotic sessile lesions in the perianal area around 4–7 mm in diameter. There is no lymphadenopathy. The application of a dilute solution of acetic acid turns the lesions white. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the lesions?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of growths around her anus that developed over the past 4 weeks. They are not painful and she does not have blood in her stool. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows nontender, irregular, hyperkeratotic sessile lesions in the perianal area around 4–7 mm in diameter. There is no lymphadenopathy. The application of a dilute solution of acetic acid turns the lesions white. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the lesions?
hint: The cauliflower-like growths in the perianal area may be treated with cryotherapy or, in more severe cases, curettage, laser surgery, or electrocoagulation.
learning_objective: Recognize condylomata acuminata, and recall its causal pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: The molluscum contagiosum (MC) virus is a DNA poxvirus that most commonly affects young children. It also affects adults, particularly those who are immunocompromised (e.g., due to HIV infection, chemotherapy, or extensive corticosteroid therapy). MC is transmitted through direct skin contact, autoinoculation, or fomites. Lesions are typically nontender and located on the face, trunk, and extremities. Sexually transmitted MC can cause lesions in the groin, lower abdomen, and genitals. In contrast to this patient's skin lesions, characteristic MC lesions are pearly, flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and smooth with a central umbilication.

images.title: Molluscum contagiosum
images.description: Photograph of the abdomen and groin of a young childSingle and grouped skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.These features are consistent with the diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum.

answers.explanation_why: T. pallidum is the pathogen responsible for syphilis. Secondary syphilis can manifest with condylomata lata, which are painless skin lesions in the anogenital region. However, condylomata lata are typically broad-based, smooth, papular erosions, not exophytic, and cauliflower-like masses. Moreover, secondary syphilis typically causes generalized lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue), which this patient does not have. Finally, acetic acid would not turn syphilitic lesions white.

images.title: Condylomata lata in secondary syphilis
images.description: Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Malignant transformation of squamous cells (i.e., SCC) is the underlying pathomechanism in the majority of patients with anal cancer. Symptoms consistent with SCC of the anus include rectal bleeding, itching, pain, lymphadenopathy, and/or anal discharge. Rather than multiple smaller growths around the anus, a larger, solitary mass in the anal canal would be more likely. If this patient had rectal bleeding or other concerning symptoms, benign causes (e.g., hemorrhoids, anal fissure, and warts) would be investigated first.

images.title: Anal cancer
images.description: A friable, exophytic mass is visible at the anal orifice.These features suggest an anal cancer.

answers.explanation_why: Benign fibroepithelial growth is the underlying cause of acrochordon (or skin tag), which is most commonly found in skin folds and is also painless. However, skin tags appear as normal folds of skin rather than cauliflower-like, and do not change over time. Additionally, they would not have a positive acetic acid skin test.

HPV strains 6 and 11 cause 90% of genital warts, or condylomata acuminata. These lesions are cauliflower-like in their appearance, with a flat, papular, or pedunculated shape, and are commonly found on the mucosa or along the epithelium of the anogenital tract. They are usually asymptomatic but may be painful or pruritic in some cases. Application of 3–5% acetic acid will turn the lesion white, though this test has poor specificity for warts since polyps or leukoplakia can also appear white. Risk factors for HPV include multiple sexual partners and unprotected sexual intercourse.

images.title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
images.description: Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with the oncogenic high-risk HPV strains (especially HPV-16 and HPV-18) may lead to precancerous and cancerous lesions. These high-risk strains account for more than 70% of cervical cancers and can also cause genital, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell cancers. However, HPV-18 is not responsible for anogenital warts.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and severe left knee pain for the past week. She has not sustained any trauma or injury to the area, nor has she traveled or taken part in outdoor activities in the recent past. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 106/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple painless pustular lesions on her ankles and the dorsum and soles of her feet bilaterally, as well as a swollen, erythematous, exquisitely tender left knee. Her wrists are also mildly edematous and tender, with pain on extension. An x-ray of the knees shows tissue swelling. Arthrocentesis of the knee shows yellow purulent fluid. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 58,000/mm^3 with 93% neutrophils and no crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of fever and severe left knee pain for the past week. She has not sustained any trauma or injury to the area, nor has she traveled or taken part in outdoor activities in the recent past. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 106/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple painless pustular lesions on her ankles and the dorsum and soles of her feet bilaterally, as well as a swollen, erythematous, exquisitely tender left knee. Her wrists are also mildly edematous and tender, with pain on extension. An x-ray of the knees shows tissue swelling. Arthrocentesis of the knee shows yellow purulent fluid. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 58,000/mm3 with 93% neutrophils and no crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: Pustular dermatitis that involves the soles of the feet, septic arthritis, and a history of inconsistent condom use suggest disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for disseminated gonococcal infection.

answers.explanation_why: Empiric therapy with IV vancomycin and ceftazidime is the treatment of choice in patients with septic arthritis if Gram stain is negative and there are no risk factors for STDs. Vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA), and ceftazidime is effective against gram-negative rods such as Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas. This patient's presentation is consistent with DGI, which requires different management.

Oral penicillin V is used to treat streptoccocal infections or for prophylaxis in diseases like rheumatic fever (RF). Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory condition that affects the heart, joints, skin, and brain and commonly develops after a streptococcal throat infection. Even though this woman fulfills one of the major criteria for RF (polyarthritis), she has no history of preceding streptoccocal infection, nor are the other criteria fulfilled (e.g., signs of carditis, erythema marginatum, Sydenham chorea, or subcutaneous nodules), making RF unlikely. RF would also not explain this patient's pustular dermatitis.

Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial drug that is also used in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) because of its anti-inflammatory effect. However, this patient lacks typical features of SLE (e.g., malar rash, weight loss, pain in the small joints) or RA (joint pain and stiffness in the hands and fingers). More importantly, the arthrocentesis results here indicate septic arthritis, whereas both RA and SLE would involve aseptic joint inflammation (leukocyte count typically < 50,000/mm^3).

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the preferred initial treatment for DGI. Although this patient only has signs of gonococcal infection, coinfection with chlamydia is common (and has not been excluded here), and oral doxycycline is used to treat it. In addition to treating the patient, testing and treatment should be offered to her sexual contacts. Although Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a bacteria that can be seen on Gram stain and routine culture of synovial fluid, these tests are positive in less than 50% of samples and are therefore unreliable. Instead, nucleic acid amplification is conducted to confirm the diagnosis.

images.title: Pustular skin lesion in disseminated gonococcal infection
images.description: Infectious pustule with accompanying erythema on the palmar side of index finger.

answers.explanation_why: Doxycycline is an antibiotic that may be used to treat Lyme disease. The disseminated form of Lyme disease can also manifest with polyarthritis. However, this patient has no history of exposure to the outdoors and patients with Lyme disease normally have erythema migrans during the first stage (before signs of dissemination), not a pustular rash. Furthermore, joint fluid analysis in Lyme disease would show aseptic inflammation (leukocyte count typically < 50,000/mm^3).
Ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for DGI. However, since chlamydial coinfection has not been excluded, ceftriaxone monotherapy would not be recommended.

Intravenous vancomycin is used to treat septic arthritis caused by gram-positive cocci. The presence of gram-positive cocci on staining indicates a staphylococcal or streptococcal infection. Typically, these infections occur in older patients, are acute, and involve one joint at a time. They are not associated with pustular rashes. The incidence of nongonococcal arthritis in individuals practicing unsafe sex (such as this patient) is lower than that of gonococcal arthritis.

question_text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for the past 3 days. She has no dysuria, dyspareunia, pruritus, or burning. The patient is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She often douches after sexual intercourse. Pelvic examination shows thin and off-white vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.1. Wet mount examination shows that a quarter of vaginal epithelial cells are covered with small coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for the past 3 days. She has no dysuria, dyspareunia, pruritus, or burning. The patient is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She often douches after sexual intercourse. Pelvic examination shows thin and off-white vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.1. Wet mount examination shows that a quarter of vaginal epithelial cells are covered with small coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Based on the color and pH value of the vaginal discharge and the wet mount showing clue cells, this patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella vaginalis.
learning_objective: Recognize bacterial vaginosis, and choose the appropriate treatment.

answers.content: Treat the patient with ceftriaxone and doxycycline
answers.explanation_why: Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and in patients with coinfection. Gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, vaginal pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia are common, together with a purulent, creamy discharge. However, this patient has no symptoms aside from a thin, off-white discharge. Additionally, if gonorrhea were present, treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days because of potentially severe complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, urethritis, and/or infertility. As doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy, a pregnancy test should be obtained before initiation of pharmacotherapy as this patient uses condoms inconsistently.

answers.content: Treat the patient and partners with metronidazole
answers.explanation_why: Metronidazole is indicated for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. However, as bacterial vaginosis is not a sexually transmitted infection, partner treatment is not routinely recommended. Antibiotic treatment for both the patient and the partner is indicated in patients with infectious vulvovaginitis caused by sexually transmitted pathogens, such as trichomoniasis, which would manifest with a frothy, foul-smelling discharge with a pH ≥ 4.5 and flagellated protozoa on a wet mount.

images.title: Trichomonas vaginalis
images.description: Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

answers.explanation_why: Ketoconazole is indicated for vaginal candidiasis, which would manifest with severe pruritus as well as an odorless, curd-like discharge.

images.title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
images.description: Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.White circles: examples of budding yeast

answers.content: Treat the patient and partners with ceftriaxone and doxycycline
answers.explanation_why: Combination therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the regimen of choice for patients with Neisseria gonorrhea infection in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and in patients with coinfection. Treatment would also be indicated for sexual partners from the last 60 days because of potentially severe complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, urethritis, and/or infertility. Gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic. If symptoms are present, vaginal pruritus, dysuria, and dyspareunia are common, together with a purulent, creamy discharge. However, this patient has no symptoms aside from a thin, off-white discharge. As doxycycline is contraindicated during pregnancy, a pregnancy test should be obtained before initiation of pharmacotherapy as this patient uses condoms inconsistently.

answers.content: Reassurance and follow-up in one week
answers.explanation_why: Reassurance would be adequate if the patient did not have vaginal discharge and if bacterial vaginosis had been incidentally diagnosed during a routine check-up. Symptomatic bacterial vaginosis, however, does require treatment.

Metronidazole is prescribed for anaerobic infections with pathogens such as Gardnerella vaginalis, the cause of bacterial vaginosis. Although sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis, this condition is not a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Bacterial vaginosis is caused by an imbalance of the vaginal flora resulting in overgrowth of Gardnerella bacteria (and a relative lack of the normally dominant lactobacilli). Another risk factor for this imbalance is vaginal douching, which this woman reports she does regularly. Bacterial vaginosis is commonly asymptomatic, but when symptomatic, individuals should receive treatment with either oral or topical metronidazole. As bacterial vaginosis is not an STI, partner treatment is not routinely recommended. The CDC recommends that women who are being treated for bacterial vaginosis refrain from sexual activity or use condoms consistently and correctly, as well as avoid douching, as it increases the risk of relapse.

images.title: Vaginal discharge in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Speculum view of the cervix with thin gray and milky discharge

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of an ulcer on his penis for the past 12 days. The ulcer is painful and draining yellow purulent material. He returned from a study abroad trip to India 3 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a 2-cm ulcer with a necrotic base proximal to the glans of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of an ulcer on his penis for the past 12 days. The ulcer is painful and draining yellow purulent material. He returned from a study abroad trip to India 3 months ago. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with one female partner and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a 2-cm ulcer with a necrotic base proximal to the glans of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: The painful necrotic ulcers and lymphadenopathy indicate chancroid.
learning_objective: Recognize chancroid, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Lymphogranuloma venereum caused by L1, L2, and L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis manifests as a transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals, with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and chills. This patient has a very painful lesion with regional lymphadenopathy and no systemic signs, making LGV unlikely.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum
images.description: Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

answers.explanation_why: Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate to form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily; regional lymph nodes are typically spared. This patient has a painful nonbleeding ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, making infection with Klebsiella granulomatis unlikely.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

answers.explanation_why: In primary syphilis, chancre appears at the site where Treponema pallidum enters the body and also typically manifests as a solitary ulcer but is painless and with indurated borders. Chancre can cause bilateral regional lymphadenopathy, however, it is usually nontender. This patient's painful sore with tender regional lymphadenopathy and purulent exudate indicates another diagnosis.

images.title: Chancre of penis (primary syphilis)
images.description:
Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

answers.explanation_why: Genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV; typically HSV2) manifests with vesicular or ulcerative lesions localized on or around the genitals. They also often cause itching, tender lymphadenopathy, and burning pain in the affected area, along with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. Although this man has tender lymph nodes, the absence of vesicles and the presence of a painful ulcer with purulent exudate make genital herpes an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: Penile shaft and glansTwo ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

answers.explanation_why: Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi. This condition manifests with a very painful lesion that is typically 2-cm in size and clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base. In men, a single lesion is common, while in women multiple lesions may be present. In addition, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treatment of chancroid is with single-dose oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

images.title: Chancroid lesion on the penis
images.description: There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

question_text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of 4-week history of lesions on his penis and scrotum. He has no pain or discharge from the lesions. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia and was treated with imatinib. He is sexually active and had unprotected intercourse with a woman about 4 months ago while abroad on business. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He takes no medications. He appears well. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Examination shows 3 nontender lesions up to 1 cm in size. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of 4-week history of lesions on his penis and scrotum. He has no pain or discharge from the lesions. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia and was treated with imatinib. He is sexually active and had unprotected intercourse with a woman about 4 months ago while abroad on business. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. He takes no medications. He appears well. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Examination shows 3 nontender lesions up to 1 cm in size. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: This patient's condition may be confirmed through the detection of Donovan bodies in ulcer smears or biopsies.
learning_objective: Recognize granuloma inguinale, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which also manifests with a genital lesion at the site where Treponema pallidum entered the body. Primary syphilis is characterized by a single genital lesion (chancre) that begins as a raised papule and subsequently develops into a painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders and a smooth base. Regional nontender lymphadenopathy is common. This patient has multiple highly vascular lesions and no lymphadenopathy.

images.title: Chancre of the glans penis in primary syphilis
images.description: A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why:
Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which is characterized by large, painless vascular lesions in the absence of inguinal lymphadenopathy that appear up to one year after exposure. Diagnosis is based primarily on clinical findings, although Donovan bodies in ulcer smears or biopsies can confirm the diagnosis. Management focuses on antibiotic treatment with azithromycin, which is continued until the ulcers have completely healed.

Even though this patient's sexual behavior puts him at increased risk and his presentation is highly characteristic of granuloma inguinale, mixed infections and bacterial superinfection are common; therefore, he should be screened for other sexually transmitted infections such as syphilis and HIV.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale (Donovaniosis)
images.description: Exudate smear (Giemsa stain)Coccobacilli are visible as inclusion bodies within macrophages (Donovan bodies). In some cases, the characteristic safety pin shape can be seen (examples indicated by arrowheads).

answers.explanation_why: Herpes simplex virus (HSV), particularly HSV type 2 causes genital herpes, which typically manifests with grouped painful vesicles, pustules, and erosions on an erythematous base and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy after an incubation period of 2–7 days. The painless lesions and lack of lymphadenopathy in this patient are not consistent with genital herpes.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: Penile shaft and glansTwo ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which may also manifest with genital lesions. However, these lesions are typically very painful and clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base. While in women multiple lesions may be present, in men, a single lesion is common. In addition, it is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, suggesting a different causal organism here.

images.title: Chancroid lesion on the penis
images.description: There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

answers.explanation_why: L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LV), which initially manifests as a solitary transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy (buboes) is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals and is accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, chills). This patient has multiple large, vascular ulcers, no regional lymphadenopathy, and no systemic signs, making LV unlikely.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum
images.description: Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital in labor. She currently has contractions occurring every 3–5 minutes. For the past 3 days, she has had burning pain in the vulvar area associated with intense itching. Her pregnancy has been uneventful. She has a history of genital herpes at the age of 16, which was treated with acyclovir. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the vulvar region. Pelvic examination shows rupture of membranes and that the cervix is 3 cm dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital in labor. She currently has contractions occurring every 3–5 minutes. For the past 3 days, she has had burning pain in the vulvar area associated with intense itching. Her pregnancy has been uneventful. She has a history of genital herpes at the age of 16, which was treated with acyclovir. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the vulvar region. Pelvic examination shows rupture of membranes and that the cervix is 3 cm dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The grouped vesicles in the vulvar region on an erythematous base indicate active genital herpes. The patient is in labor, as she is having contractions and her cervix is dilated 3 cm. What will prevent the newborn from acquiring a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection?
learning_objective: Recognize active genital herpes in labor, and choose the appropriate delivery method and antiviral therapy.

answers.content: Tocolytic therapy until lesions are crusted
answers.explanation_why: Suppressing labor via tocolytics would not be a practical solution to preventing vertical transmission. Herpetic lesions take 10–12 days to crust and tocolytic agents are generally not recommended for more than 48 hours (although some may be effective for several more days). Additionally, the virus may still be present in maternal secretions even after initial crusting.

Topical acyclovir is less effective than oral acyclovir at reducing the symptoms of genital herpes. Although oral acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes, which is why cesarean delivery is indeed recommended to prevent neonatal herpes.

answers.content: Oral acyclovir therapy and vaginal delivery
answers.explanation_why: Although acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes. Additionally, vaginal delivery would expose the newborn to HSV in maternal secretions and increase the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

Topical acyclovir is less effective than oral acyclovir at reducing the symptoms of genital herpes. Although oral acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes. Additionally, vaginal delivery would expose the newborn to HSV in maternal secretions and increase the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

answers.content: Oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery
answers.explanation_why:
The risk for vertical transmission to the neonate from an infected mother is high (up to 50%) among women who exhibit active genital herpes near the time of delivery. Cesarean delivery is indicated in women with recurrent and active genital herpes at the onset of labor to reduce the risk of transmission and thereby prevent neonatal HSV, which could result in severe complications like disseminated disease or meningoencephalitis. Although oral acyclovir does not prevent vertical transmission, it will help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. In severe infection, IV acyclovir should be considered. If HSV lesions are not genital, delivery can proceed as normal. After birth, breastfeeding can also continue as usual unless lesions are on the breast.

Oral acyclovir can be used as suppressive therapy for genital herpes after 36 weeks' gestation until delivery in women with a prior history of genital herpes.

Active genital herpes during vaginal delivery increases the risk of vertical transmission, as it exposes the newborn to HSV in the maternal secretions, which can result in neonatal HSV and life-threatening complications.

question_text: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician with a 4-day history of painful vulvar lesions, generalized fatigue, and malaise. During this period, she has also had dysuria. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date; she completed the vaccination course for human papillomavirus 2 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora. The ulcers are 1–3 mm in diameter. There is bilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl comes to the physician with a 4-day history of painful vulvar lesions, generalized fatigue, and malaise. During this period, she has also had dysuria. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date; she completed the vaccination course for human papillomavirus 2 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base over the labia majora and minora. The ulcers are 1–3 mm in diameter. There is bilateral, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: The presence of several shallow ulcers on an erythematous base and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy in an individual with high-risk sexual behavior is indicative of genital herpes, which is diagnosed by performing a polymerase chain reaction test or viral culture on a smear obtained from the ulcer.
learning_objective: Recognize genital herpes, and choose the most appropriate antiviral therapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Oral acyclovir therapy is indicated for genital herpes. Antiviral treatment reduces the duration and severity of infection as well as viral shedding, and it is most effective if initiated within 72 hours of symptom onset. Antiviral therapy does not prevent recurrence.

See “Overview of sexually transmitted genital lesions” table.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why: Curettage is used to treat warts (caused by human papillomavirus) but not genital herpes. Genital warts can be transmitted sexually but present as painless papular growths and are not associated with tender lymphadenopathy, multiple painful shallow ulcers, or malaise, making this diagnosis very unlikely. Additionally, if this patient received a tetravalent or 9-valent vaccine regimen prior to potential infection, she would likely be immune to the HPV types (primarily 6 and 11) that cause genital warts.

Azithromycin is commonly used in the treatment of sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and chancroid. Chlamydia infection is commonly asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients typically present with pelvic pain, not skin lesions and lymphadenopathy. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi and manifests with multiple painful papules or pustules that erode into ulcers. Chancroid ulcers are usually larger (10–20 mm) and deeper than the ones seen here, and they have a greyish necrotic base and purulent exudate.

Doxycycline can be used to treat both syphilitic and chlamydial infections but not genital herpes. L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which manifests initially with a painless papule that resolves and then causes suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–6 weeks later. Treponema pallidum is responsible for syphilis, which manifests in the primary stage as a painless round and firm ulcer with no lymph node involvement. Neither syphilis nor LGV are associated with multiple painful shallow ulcers, making them unlikely diagnoses.

Benzathine penicillin is effective against Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis. The primary stage of syphilis presents as a painless round ulcer called chancre that is typically a solitary lesion but can occasionally present with multiple lesions or bilateral lymphadenopathy. However, the lesion is generally painless.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and generalized fatigue. Yesterday, he developed a rash all over his body. Two months ago, he had a painless lesion on his penis that resolved a few weeks later without treatment. He has asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler. He is currently sexually active with 3 different partners. He uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. He has a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles. An HIV test is negative. Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) and fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) are positive. The patient receives a dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G. Two hours later, he reports headache, myalgias, and chills. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 98/67 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and generalized fatigue. Yesterday, he developed a rash all over his body. Two months ago, he had a painless lesion on his penis that resolved a few weeks later without treatment. He has asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler. He is currently sexually active with 3 different partners. He uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. He has a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles. An HIV test is negative. Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) and fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) are positive. The patient receives a dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G. Two hours later, he reports headache, myalgias, and chills. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 98/67 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: The patient has signs of secondary syphilis (generalized maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles), a few weeks after primary infection (painless penile lesion). A positive FTA-ABS test confirms the diagnosis. A common complication of treatment is the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.
learning_objective: Recognize the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Ceftriaxone is indicated as an alternative treatment option for syphilis. However, this patient currently requires treatment for a complication he developed following therapy of the infection.

NSAIDs such as ibuprofen are recommended for the treatment of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR). After administration of antibiotic treatment (usually in the early phases of the secondary stage of syphilis), the release of bacterial endotoxins and pyrogens can elicit a systemic reaction consisting of flu-like symptoms (fever, chills, headache, myalgia), tachypnea, hypotension, and tachycardia. JHR is a common complication of treatment of spirochetal infections (e.g., borreliosis, leptospirosis, syphilis) and is usually self-limiting within 12–24 hours.

Epinephrine is commonly used to treat anaphylactic reactions. While these may occur following medical treatment (e.g., with antibiotics) and may manifest with skin lesions, they are typically urticarial and not maculopapular. Since fever and myalgias are not caused by anaphylaxis and further typical symptoms (e.g., erythema, angioedema, dyspnea) are absent in this patient, the diagnosis is unlikely and treatment with epinephrine is not necessary.

Methylprednisolone is a steroidal antiinflammatory drug. Although it is effective in reducing inflammation in several conditions (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, allergies, asthma), it is not indicated for the treatment of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

Phenylephrine is most commonly used as a decongestant, but can also be indicated as a vasopressor to treat hypotension (e.g., secondary to shock). While this patient experienced a drop in blood pressure, treatment for hypotension should be considered if blood pressure drops below 90/60 mm Hg and is therefore not required in this patient.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a rash that began 3 days ago. She has low-grade fever and muscle aches. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has had 5 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 126/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a rash that began 3 days ago. She has low-grade fever and muscle aches. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has had 5 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 126/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Low-grade fever, myalgias, and a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles are features of secondary syphilis. To confirm the diagnosis of syphilis, a positive nontreponemal test (NTT), such as VDRL, must be followed by a more specific test.
learning_objective: Recognize secondary syphilis, and choose the confirmatory test following a positive nontreponemal test.

answers.explanation_why: Nontreponemal tests, such as the VDRL and the rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test, are sensitive but not specific for syphilis infection. This patient has symptoms consistent with syphilis and has already tested positive on a nontreponemal test; therefore, a positive treponemal test is required to confirm the diagnosis. Nontreponemal tests are performed to screen for infection, evaluate disease activity, and monitor response to treatment.

Although bacterial cultures are used to detect a wide variety of pathogens, they cannot be used in the diagnosis of syphilis. Treponema are obligate intracellular organisms that can only survive in mammalian cells and cannot be cultured in the laboratory.

Intravenous penicillin is the treatment of choice for neurosyphilis. However, this patient does not present with any symptoms suggestive of neurosyphilis (e.g., tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupil). Furthermore, treatment should not be initiated until diagnosis has been confirmed since the VDRL test yields many false-positive results due to cross-reacting antibodies in patients with viral infections, rheumatic fever, lupus, or leprosy.

Dark-field microscopy is capable of directly visualizing Treponema pallidum and is one of two definitive tests for detecting primary and secondary syphilis (PCR is the other), although it has been replaced in many settings by serological testing. It requires a specimen that is taken from a skin lesion that contains high amounts of treponemes and only few blood cells (e.g., chancre, condyloma). However, this patient does not present with a chancre (primary syphilis) or condylomata lata (secondary syphilis).

A single dose of intramuscular penicillin is the treatment of choice for primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis infection. Although this patient most likely has secondary syphilis, treatment should not be initiated until the diagnosis has been confirmed since the VDRL test yields many false-positive results due to cross-reacting antibodies in patients with viral infections, rheumatic fever, lupus, or leprosy.

Doxycycline, a tetracycline, may be used to treat rickettsial and chlamydial infections. Doxycycline is also a treatment option for patients with syphilis who are allergic to penicillin. Although this patient most likely has secondary syphilis, treatment should not be initiated until the diagnosis has been confirmed since the venereal disease research laboratory VDRL test often yields false-positive results due to cross-reacting antibodies in patients with viral infections, rheumatic fever, lupus, or leprosy.

Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) and Treponema pallidum particle agglutination (TPPA) assay are treponemal tests (TTs). The diagnosis of syphilis is confirmed using a serial testing strategy. In the standard testing algorithm, an NTT (e.g., VDRL, plasma reagin test) is performed first. If the result is positive or equivocal, a TT is performed. In the reverse testing algorithm, a TT is performed first, followed by an NTT test. A positive result for both tests strongly supports the diagnosis of syphilis. FTA-ABS tests become positive 2–3 weeks after infection and have a very high positive predictive value. Because treponemal tests usually remain positive regardless of treatment or disease activity, a positive FTA-ABS indicates either active syphilis infection or persistent antibodies from a prior infection.

question_text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the physician with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count; urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the physician with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count; urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This sexually active young man has dysuria, a tender testicle, a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), and increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasonography, indicating epididymitis.
learning_objective: Recognize Chlamydia trachomatis infection as a cause of epididymitis.

answers.explanation_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

Hydatid of Morgagni torsion would also cause acute scrotal pain. But it does not cause dysuria and the ultrasound would not show increased vascularity, but rather an enlarged hydatid along with normal testes.

Testicular torsion commonly manifests with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. Additionally, testicular torsion does not involve dysuria, and the Doppler ultrasound would show reduced perfusion to the affected testicle.

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. C. trachomatis can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Treatment of C. trachomatis epididymitis consists of ceftriaxone and doxycycline (see “Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain” table).

Escherichia coli is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, men > 35 years, and men who engage in anal intercourse, but this sexually active young man has no such risk factors. Moreover, E. coli would have likely shown up as gram-negative rods on Gram staining.

Varicocele can present with acute scrotal pain, as seen in this man, but it does not cause dysuria and leukocytes on urethral swab. Palpation of a varicocele often reveals the dilated pampiniform venous plexus. Additionally, ultrasound would clearly show the dilated hypoechoic veins, which is not the case here.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe burning with urination for the past 3 days. During this period, he has had clear urethral discharge early in the morning. He has no history of serious illness. The patient takes no medications. He is sexually active with one male and one female partner; they use condoms inconsistently. His younger brother was diagnosed with Crohn disease at the age of 24 years. The patient does not smoke. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. He appears well. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.0°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Gram stain of a urethral swab shows neutrophils but no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe burning with urination for the past 3 days. During this period, he has had clear urethral discharge early in the morning. He has no history of serious illness. The patient takes no medications. He is sexually active with one male and one female partner; they use condoms inconsistently. His younger brother was diagnosed with Crohn disease at the age of 24 years. The patient does not smoke. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. He appears well. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.0°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 135/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Gram stain of a urethral swab shows neutrophils but no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
hint: Dysuria and clear urethral discharge in the absence of systemic signs of inflammation (fever, chills) suggest urethritis. What is the most common cause of urethritis in a patient with a negative Gram stain?
learning_objective: Recognize nongonococcal urethritis, and recall its most common cause.

answers.explanation_why: Neisseria gonorrhea is a common cause of urethritis. However, the urethral discharge in gonococcal urethritis is typically purulent, and the Gram stain would have shown gram-negative intracellular (within neutrophils) or extracellular diplococci.
Mycoplasma genitalium can cause urethritis with clear urethral discharge and a negative Gram stain. However, it is an uncommon cause of these symptoms and a different pathogen is much more likely.

Gardnerella vaginalis is a rare cause of urethritis. Gardnerella infection is characterized by clue cells on microscopy. The absence of organisms on the Gram stain of this patient's urethral swab suggests a different diagnosis.

Trichomonas vaginalis is a common cause of urethritis. Although a wet mount or culture is usually the method of choice for detecting trichomoniasis, Gram staining can also be used to detect trichomonads. Because the Gram stain did not show any organisms, trichomoniasis can be ruled out.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of nongonococcal urethritis which is often asymptomatic but may cause clear urethral discharge. C. trachomatis is an intracellular organism that is notoriously difficult to stain, which explains why neutrophils are seen (indicating bacterial infection) but no organisms. The typical screening test for chlamydia would be DNA amplification.

This patient does not use condoms consistently, which puts him at risk of acquiring sexually transmitted infections such as C. trachomatis.

Herpes simplex virus can cause mucosal infections, including urethritis with no organisms on a Gram stain. Infections typically manifest with ulcerative genital lesions and associated local lymphadenopathy.
