question_text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressive left-sided scrotal pain for 4 hours. He describes the pain as throbbing in nature and 6 out of 10 in intensity. He has vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had pain during urination for the past 4 days. He had an episode of similar pain 1 year ago that resolved spontaneously. He underwent surgery for a left-sided inguinal hernia as a child. He has been sexually active with 2 female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears anxious. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows a tender, swollen left testicle and a firm and erythematous left hemiscrotum. The left testicle ascends when the medial portion of the left thigh is stroked. Urine dipstick shows positive leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of progressive left-sided scrotal pain for 4 hours. He describes the pain as throbbing in nature and 6 out of 10 in intensity. He has vomited once on the way to the hospital. He has had pain during urination for the past 4 days. He had an episode of similar pain 1 year ago that resolved spontaneously. He underwent surgery for a left-sided inguinal hernia as a child. He has been sexually active with 2 female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears anxious. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows a tender, swollen left testicle and a firm and erythematous left hemiscrotum. The left testicle ascends when the medial portion of the left thigh is stroked. Urine dipstick shows positive leukocyte esterase. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's high risk sexual behavior, dysuria, and pyuria (positive leukocyte esterase) are consistent with epididymitis but his young age, the sudden onset of scrotal pain, and the presence of vomiting and testicular swelling also increase the likelihood of a condition that can result in permanent morbidity if not detected and treated within 6 hours of symptom onset.
learning_objective: Recognize the potential for testicular torsion in a patient with acute testicular pain, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Fluoroquinolones (e.g., levofloxacin) can be used to treat epididymitis in older patients, in whom this condition is most commonly secondary to urinary tract infections. Since epididymitis in young, sexually active male individuals is most frequently caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a combination of ceftriaxone and doxycycline is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic treatment for this patient. Moreover, his presentation makes a different step in management necessary.

answers.content: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is typically used in the workup of an acute abdomen. It may also be used in the workup of suspected torsion of an undescended testis. Imaging modalities such as CT scan, MRI, and scintigraphy play no role in the initial workup of this patient who has symptoms of an acute scrotum and no cryptorchidism.

Immediate surgical exploration is indicated if clinical features indicate a definitive diagnosis of testicular torsion. Although this patient's presentation increases the likelihood of testicular torsion, the diagnosis of testicular torsion is not yet conclusive at this time because of an intact cremasteric reflex, the absence of a hard and high-riding testis, and the presence of features of epididymitis. A different step in management should be performed first.

While epididymitis is the most likely cause of this patient's acute testicular pain, the most dangerous differential diagnosis is testicular torsion. In patients with acute testicular pain, an absent cremasteric reflex is relatively specific for testicular torsion but the presence of a cremasteric reflex does not rule out the condition. For this patient, a scrotal ultrasound is necessary to definitively rule out testicular torsion. If testicular torsion is not corrected early by surgery, testicular ischemia will result in necrosis and loss of the testicle. Scrotal ultrasound is also performed as a part of the management of epididymitis in order to rule out a scrotal abscess, a common complication that may require surgical drainage.
answers.explanation_but: Risk stratification scores (e.g., TWIST score) can be used to formally assess the risk of testicular torsion. For your exam, it is not necessary to know how to calculate the TWIST score but to follow this principle: always consider testicular torsion in a patient with acute testicular pain and if testicular torsion cannot be ruled out clinically with a high level of certainty, perform a scrotal ultrasound.

answers.content: Measurement of serum mumps IgG titer
answers.explanation_why: Orchitis can manifest with a unilateral swollen and tender testicle in conjunction with nausea and vomiting. Orchitis may be a complication of infection with the mumps virus, which can be confirmed by positive serology (e.g., IgG antibody titer). However, in mumps orchitis, a sudden onset of fever is expected. Furthermore, the classic course of mumps infection includes a prodromal phase with low-grade fever, respiratory symptoms, malaise, and headache, followed by parotitis, which is not consistent with this patient's clinical presentation.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a painless lump on his penis. He first noticed the lesion 1 year ago but was too embarrassed to mention it at his last annual physical examination. The lesion has since grown in size and has recently become erythematous. At age 45, he was successfully treated for phimosis with a steroid cream. He first engaged in sexual intercourse at age 14 and has had “too many sexual partners to count” in his lifetime. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Physical examination shows a nontender, ulcerated, 5 × 5 mm lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's biopsy specimen?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a painless lump on his penis. He first noticed the lesion 1 year ago but was too embarrassed to mention it at his last annual physical examination. The lesion has since grown in size and has recently become erythematous. At age 45, he was successfully treated for phimosis with a steroid cream. He first engaged in sexual intercourse at age 14 and has had “too many sexual partners to count” in his lifetime. He has hypertension treated with lisinopril. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. Physical examination shows a nontender, ulcerated, 5 × 5 mm lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. Excisional biopsy of the lesion is performed. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on this patient's biopsy specimen?
hint: What disease is most likely to cause a small, chronic, painless, slow-growing ulcerative penile lesion without systemic symptoms or lymphadenopathy in a patient with a history of phimosis, high-risk sexual behavior, and smoking?
learning_objective: Recognize squamous cell carcinoma of the penis, and recall its histopathological features.

answers.content: Atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity
answers.explanation_why: Atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity are diagnostic of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), the most common carcinoma of the penis. This patient's lesion has been growing for a year now, which should raise suspicion of cancer. Additionally, he has three independent risk factors for SCC of the penis, including phimosis, smoking, and a sexual history that predisposes him to HPV infection. Considering the chronic nature of the lesion and this patient's personal history, his biopsy will most likely show histopathological findings of SCC.

Spirochetes on dark-field microscopy are diagnostic of syphilis. Although primary syphilis causes painless penile lesions which begin as papules that then ulcerate, these lesions resolve within 3–6 weeks and are associated with inguinal lymphadenopathy. This patient's lesion has been present for at least 1 year and is not associated with lymphadenopathy.

answers.content: Nonspecific inflammatory features with Chlamydia trachomatis amplification on PCR
answers.explanation_why: Chlamydia trachomatis amplification on PCR may be seen in patients with lymphogranuloma venereum, which can also manifest with painless genital ulcers. However, the onset of genital ulcers is generally acute, and most lesions resolve within a couple of days before progressing to secondary infection with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) and abscess formation. While this patient is at risk for sexually transmitted infections such as C. trachomatis infection, his chronic, slow-growing ulcerative lesion is inconsistent with lymphogranuloma venereum.

answers.content: Multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smear
answers.explanation_why: Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear indicate a herpes simplex virus infection. Genital herpes infection usually manifests with painful red bumps or white vesicles, whereas this patient's lesion is painless. Additionally, herpetic lesions eventually resolve within ∼ 10 days and do not persist and/or worsen over the course of a year.

answers.content: Safety pin-shaped intracellular inclusions that appear purple on Giemsa stain
answers.explanation_why: The presence of Donovan bodies is the characteristic histopathological finding in granuloma inguinale. Although granuloma inguinale also causes chronic, painless, penile lesions, the lesions are typically large, beefy-red with a rolled edge, and bleed easily. This patient's lesion is smaller, without a rolled edge, and there is no history of bleeding.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lesion on his penis. There is no history of itching or pain associated with the lesion. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Five weeks ago, he returned from a trip to the Caribbean with some of his football teammates. He has recently started an intense exercise program. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple enlarged, nontender lymph nodes in the inguinal area bilaterally. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lesion on his penis. There is no history of itching or pain associated with the lesion. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Five weeks ago, he returned from a trip to the Caribbean with some of his football teammates. He has recently started an intense exercise program. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple enlarged, nontender lymph nodes in the inguinal area bilaterally. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
hint: The lesion will evolve into an ulcer and spontaneously resolve if left untreated. However, the infection will manifest again after approximately 8 weeks with a diffuse, polymorphic, copper-colored rash involving the palms and soles.
learning_objective: Recognize Treponema pallidum as the cause of syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Trichophyton rubrum is a common cause of tinea cruris, which manifests with pruritus and scaly erythema of the groin and adjacent skin that may worsen with exercise rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in this patient.

images.title: Tinea cruris
images.description: There is a sharply demarcated, light gray lesion with a raised border and scaling around the pubic area and upper thighs.These findings are consistent with tinea cruris.

answers.explanation_why: While a sexually transmitted disease such as infection with Mycoplasma genitalium is not unlikely in a sexually active young man, symptomatic disease in a male patient would manifest with symptoms of urethritis (e.g., dysuria, urethral discharge) rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

Human papillomavirus infection commonly results in condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts). Patients present with multiple painless, cauliflower-like lesions on the penis and/or perineal region rather than the genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

images.title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
images.description: Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection that can manifest with a genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, both the genital ulcer and the lymph nodes will be severely painful, unlike the painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy seen here.

images.title: Inguinal lymphadenopathy in chancroid
images.description: There is massive bilateral swelling of inguinal lymph nodes. The skin above the lymph nodes is livid. The causative agent is Haemophilus ducreyi.

answers.explanation_why:
Treponema pallidum causes the sexually transmitted infection syphilis. In the earliest stage of syphilis (primary syphilis), patients present with a painless papule that evolves into an ulcer with a smooth base and indurated border (chancre) at the site of inoculation, as seen here. Painless, nonsuppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance. If left untreated, the disease progresses after a period of 8–12 weeks to secondary syphilis with generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, polymorphic rash, fever, condylomata lata, and/or patchy alopecia. Finally, tertiary syphilis can cause cardiovascular manifestations (e.g., ascending aortic aneurysm) and neurosyphilis.

The presence of characteristic clinical features and positive serology raises suspicion for syphilis. Dark-field microscopy or PCR showing Treponema pallidum in exudate from the chancre confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, the patient should be offered HIV testing and screening for other sexually transmitted infections, as his syphilis infection is indicative of high-risk sexual behavior. Treatment of primary syphilis consists of a single intramuscular injection of penicillin G.

Herpes simplex virus type 2 is a common cause of genital herpes, which can manifest with genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy. However, patients typically have multiple flat, painful erosions on an erythematous base, unlike the single painless ulcer with raised, non-inflamed margins seen here. Lymphadenopathy is usually tender, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and headache would also be expected.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: Penile shaft and glansTwo ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

answers.explanation_why: Serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LV), a sexually transmitted disease that can cause painless genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. LV is more common in subtropical and tropical countries, such as the Caribbean, putting this patient at increased risk. However, the ulcer is usually small and shallow and disappears by the time lymphadenopathy is apparent. Furthermore, lymphadenopathy would be quite painful, unlike the painless inguinal lymph nodes seen here. Also, patients frequently have systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, and myalgia.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)
images.description: A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

answers.explanation_why: While a sexually transmitted disease such as infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not unlikely in a sexually active young man, gonorrhea in a male patient would manifest with symptoms of urethritis (e.g., dysuria, purulent urethral discharge) rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted infection that is endemic in tropical and subtropical countries, such as the Caribbean. Patients may present with a painless genital ulcer, but the ulcer has a red, beefy appearance (due to the vascular nature of the lesion) and typically does not cause regional lymphadenopathy.

images.title: Chancre of penis (primary syphilis)
images.description:
Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

question_text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: In a sexually active adolescent, the presence of multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules indicates human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.
learning_objective: Recognize genital warts due to HPV infection, and choose the most effective prevention strategy for this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Although condom use may help reduce the risk of HPV transmission, studies have shown that contact with uncovered areas still allows for HPV transmission. Condom use is therefore not the best option for preventing this patient's condition.

HIV can present with genital lesions in a sexually active individual. Molluscum contagiosum, which is a common genital lesion in adults associated with HIV, could present with a nontender, exophytic papule on the genitalia. However, these lesions would have a characteristic hemispherical, umbilicated appearance, and they would not turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Moreover, there are no other features in this patient that suggest immunocompromise, which is typical of HIV.

Spermicidal foams and gels are means of contraception with medium efficacy and may be used by sexually active individuals who do not intend to get pregnant. However, they do not provide any protection against sexually transmitted infections, such as the one in this case.

Famciclovir is used for the treatment and prophylaxis of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2). A case of genital herpes could present with multiple raised lesions over the vulva. However, the lesions would be vesicular or ulcerative, very painful, and associated with systemic features (like fever, lymphadenopathy, etc.), which are not seen in this patient.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient presents with condylomata acuminata, which are genital warts caused by HPV. HPV vaccines are recommended by the CDC to all persons aged 9–26 years and are most effective before exposure to HPV via sexual activity; they are routinely administered at 11–12 years of age. The tetravalent and 9-valent vaccines provide ∼ 99% coverage against the types of HPV most commonly implicated in genital warts (types 6 and 11) and in cervical cancer (especially types 16 and 18) for at least 10 years after vaccination (likely longer, but data is only available for that time period). Given this patient's sexual history, HPV vaccine would most likely have prevented this condition.

Some older HPV vaccines (e.g., Cervarix®) do not cover the types of HPV associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) and only protect against cervical cancer.

images.title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
images.description: Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless lesions on the vulva that she first noticed 2 days ago. She does not have any urinary symptoms. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease for which she takes omeprazole. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows clusters of several 3- to 5-mm raised lesions with a rough texture on the vulva. The lesions turn white after application of a dilute acetic acid solution. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painless lesions on the vulva that she first noticed 2 days ago. She does not have any urinary symptoms. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease for which she takes omeprazole. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows clusters of several 3- to 5-mm raised lesions with a rough texture on the vulva. The lesions turn white after application of a dilute acetic acid solution. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Clusters of nonpainful raised, rough-textured genital lesions that whiten after application of acetic acid suggests condylomata acuminata, which is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV).
learning_objective: Recognize condylomata acuminata, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Benzathine penicillin is indicated for the treatment of syphilis, for which this patient's sexual activity puts her at risk. Secondary syphilis may manifest with condylomata lata. However, condylomata lata are nonverrucous, flat-topped papules, and would not change color upon application of acetic acid.

images.title: Condylomata lata in secondary syphilis
images.description: Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Cryotherapy, curettage, laser surgery, and electrocoagulation are all appropriate destructive treatment options for condylomata acuminata, especially in cases involving numerous warts. Pharmacotherapy options include local cytostatic treatment (e.g., trichloroacetic acid, podofilox) and immune response modifiers (e.g., imiquimod). The rate of recurrence is high.

images.title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
images.description: Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

answers.explanation_why: Mometasone is a steroid indicated for the treatment of lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin. Typical lichen planus lesions are pruritic, planar, polygonal, purple papules and plaques (the 6 Ps of lichen planus), unlike this patient's lesions. This condition usually involves flexural surfaces of the extremities but can also affect the genitalia. Moreover, lesions do not change color upon application of acetic acid.

images.title: Cutaneous lichen planus
images.description: Scattered, partially coalescent violaceous papules, macules, and plaques are visible on the shins.

answers.explanation_why: Radiotherapy may be indicated for vulva cancer, which is typically a slow-growing squamous cell carcinoma. Vulvar cancer can manifest with cauliflower-like growths, but the sudden onset and lack of other features (e.g., pruritus, leukoplakia, lymphadenopathy, or bleeding ulcerations) make vulvar cancer unlikely.

images.title: Vulvar squamous cell carcinoma
images.description: The labia minora and majora are difficult to identify due to the destructive, ulcerative, and exophytic growth of the tumor. The affected region shows a livid discoloration with bloody lesions.These findings are suggestive of a squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy.

answers.explanation_why: Acyclovir is used to treat genital herpes, which typically manifests with painful, erosive vesicles that are accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy in the groin area. This patient does not have lymphadenopathy or tender vesicles, making genital herpes unlikely.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

question_text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple painful, purulent ulcers she noticed on her vulva 2 days ago. The patient has not had fever or burning with urination. She has no history of similar lesions. She had a chlamydial infection at 17 years of age that was treated with antibiotics. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is sexually active with her boyfriend of 2 months and uses an oral contraceptive; they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are 4 tender, purulent 1.5-cm ulcers with a necrotic base along the labia majora. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of multiple painful, purulent ulcers she noticed on her vulva 2 days ago. The patient has not had fever or burning with urination. She has no history of similar lesions. She had a chlamydial infection at 17 years of age that was treated with antibiotics. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She is sexually active with her boyfriend of 2 months and uses an oral contraceptive; they use condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg. Examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. There are 4 tender, purulent 1.5-cm ulcers with a necrotic base along the labia majora. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The painful necrotic ulcers and lymphadenopathy suggest a sexually transmitted infection with a gram-negative organism.
learning_objective: Recognize chancroid.

answers.explanation_why: Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi. In women, chancroid manifests with multiple purulent lesions that are 1–2 cm in size, clearly demarcated with a greyish necrotic base, and typically very painful. In men, a single lesion is common. In addition, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Treatment of chancroid is with single-dose oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

Granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate to form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily; regional lymph nodes are typically spared. This patient shows nonbleeding ulcers and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, making infection with Klebsiella granulomatis unlikely.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infectionMultiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

answers.explanation_why: Genital herpes caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV; typically HSV2) manifests with vesicular or ulcerative lesions localized on or around the genitals. They also often cause itching, tender lymphadenopathy, and burning pain in the affected area, along with systemic symptoms of fever and malaise. Although this woman has tender lymph nodes, the absence of vesicles and the presence of painful ulcers with purulent exudate make genital herpes an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why: In primary syphilis, chancre appears at the site where Treponema pallidum enters the body, and although multiple lesions are possible, chancre typically manifests as a solitary painless ulcer with indurated borders. Chancre can cause bilateral regional lymphadenopathy, but lymphadenopathy is also nontender. The multiple, painful sores with regional lymphadenopathy and purulent exudate in this patient indicate another diagnosis.

images.title: Chancres on the labium in primary syphilis
images.description: A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.

answers.explanation_why: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) caused by L1, L2, and L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis manifests as a transient papule that is painless and heals rapidly without scarring. Painful suppurative lymphadenopathy is seen 2–6 weeks after the papule heals, with systemic symptoms like fever, malaise, and chills. This patient has multiple, very painful lesions with regional lymphadenopathy, but does not have any systemic signs, making LGV a less likely diagnosis.

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 4 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Twelve months ago, she was diagnosed with trichomoniasis, for which she and her partner were treated with a course of an antimicrobial. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive that she has been taking for the past 4 years. A Gram stain of her vaginal fluid is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 4 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Twelve months ago, she was diagnosed with trichomoniasis, for which she and her partner were treated with a course of an antimicrobial. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive that she has been taking for the past 4 years. A Gram stain of her vaginal fluid is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: The Gram stain shows gram-negative intracellular diplococci – the pathogen responsible for a common sexually transmitted infection (STI).
learning_objective: Recognize gonorrhea, and recall its characteristic Gram stain findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is responsible for gonorrhea, an STI that presents with purulent, creamy vaginal discharge. This patient's history of inconsistent condom use and previous trichomoniasis indicates an elevated risk of future STIs. The presence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci in the microscopy of this patient's discharge specimen confirms that the infection is caused by N. gonorrhoeae.

Because Gram stain is often false negative, the test of choice for detecting gonorrhea is the nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).

Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram-variable rod that can commonly cause infections of the genitourinary tract (bacterial vaginosis) associated with a painless vaginal discharge. However, the discharge in bacterial vaginosis has a characteristic fishy odor. Moreover, microscopy would characteristically contain 'Clue cells', which are vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria. The absence of these hallmark features makes this an unlikely causal agent.

images.title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus ducreyi causes a highly contagious STI called chancroid. Although this organism could appear as a gram-negative coccobacillus on microscopy, it causes both highly painful lesions and lymphadenopathy. The absence of these hallmark features makes this an unlikely causative agent.

Klebsiella granulomatis is a gram-negative bacillus that causes granuloma inguinale. Although this patient demonstrates an elevated risk of STI contraction (as evidenced by inconsistent condom use, with a history of previous STI), granuloma inguinale would typically present with painless genital lesions. Also, the absence of gram-negative bacilli in the microscopy of this patient's discharge specimen confirms that the infection is not caused by this bacterium.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infectionMultiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

answers.explanation_why: Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common sexually transmitted genitourinary infection. The majority of patients are asymptomatic or present with purulent vaginal discharge, as seen here. A Gram stain would not show intracellular diplococci; this pathogen can be detected by Giemsa stain, but sensitivity is low; so it is usually identified using PCR (nucleic acid amplification test).

Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Although C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically associated with intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Also, microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide and would not include gram staining.

T. pallidum causes syphilis. The characteristic genital lesion of primary syphilis (raised genital papule that evolves into a painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders) is not seen in this patient, nor is associated lymphadenopathy. Also, T. pallidum does not gram stain well and is too small to be seen in conventional light microscopy. Instead, T. pallidum is visualized with dark field microscopy and appears as thin, corkscrew-shaped spirochetes.

images.title: Neisseria gonorrhoeae
images.description: Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

question_text: A sexually active 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of itching in the area of his genitals. He also reports burning on micturition. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with oral metformin. Pelvic examination shows tender, atrophic white papules on the glans and prepuce, with erythema of the surrounding skin. The urinary meatus is narrowed and sclerotic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A sexually active 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of itching in the area of his genitals. He also reports burning on micturition. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with oral metformin. Pelvic examination shows tender, atrophic white papules on the glans and prepuce, with erythema of the surrounding skin. The urinary meatus is narrowed and sclerotic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: White, atrophic papules on the glans and prepuce of a male, associated with pruritus and scarring of the urethral meatus are indicative of lichen sclerosus.
learning_objective: Recognize lichen sclerosus, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.content: Test lesion with acetic acid application
answers.explanation_why: Application of acetic acid can be used to identify genital warts because HPV-infected skin or mucosa stains white with acetic acid. Genital warts can appear as papules on the glans but erythema, itching, and dysuria would not be present.
A superpotent topical corticosteroid such as clobetasol can be used to treat lichen sclerosus. However, a different step is required before therapy can be initiated.

Topical fluconazole would be used to treat candidiasis. Candidal balanitis would appear as itchy, white lesions on the glans surrounded by erythema; candidal cystitis can result in dysuria. However, atrophy of the epidermis of the glans, and sclerosis of the urethral meatus would not be expected.

Adult patients with lichen sclerosus are at increased risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma. A punch biopsy of the lesion should be performed to rule out dysplastic changes or squamous cell carcinoma. Once neoplastic changes are ruled out, the lesions can be treated with highly potent topical steroids such as clobetasol. Patients who have not been circumcised should be advised to undergo circumcision. If lichen sclerosus causes scarring of the urethral meatus that is severe enough to affect urine outflow, a meatoplasty should be performed.

images.title: Lichen sclerosus of preputial skin
images.description: Irregularly shaped, slightly hard white plaque surrounded by an inflammatory halo on the preputial skin. When retracted, the foreskin appears entrapped and constricts the penile shaft; this is most likely pathologic phimosis.

answers.explanation_why: A KOH mount of scraping from the glans can be used to diagnose a fungal infection such as candidiasis. Candidal balanitis would appear as itchy, white lesions on the glans surrounded by erythema; candidal cystitis can result in dysuria. However, atrophy of the epidermis of the glans, and sclerosis of the urethral meatus would not be expected.

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chills and numerous skin lesions for 1 week. He has also had watery diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The skin lesions are nonpruritic and painless. He was diagnosed with HIV infection approximately 20 years ago. He has not taken any medications for over 5 years. He sleeps in homeless shelters and parks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several bright red, friable nodules on his face, trunk, and extremities. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm^3. A rapid plasma reagin test is negative. Abdominal ultrasonography shows hepatomegaly and a single intrahepatic 1.0 x 1.2-cm hypodense lesion. Biopsy of a skin lesion shows vascular proliferation and abundant neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chills and numerous skin lesions for 1 week. He has also had watery diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks. The skin lesions are nonpruritic and painless. He was diagnosed with HIV infection approximately 20 years ago. He has not taken any medications for over 5 years. He sleeps in homeless shelters and parks. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several bright red, friable nodules on his face, trunk, and extremities. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. A rapid plasma reagin test is negative. Abdominal ultrasonography shows hepatomegaly and a single intrahepatic 1.0 x 1.2-cm hypodense lesion. Biopsy of a skin lesion shows vascular proliferation and abundant neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: Cats are the main host of this pathogen, which is most commonly transmitted through bites, scratches, and fleas.
learning_objective: Recognize bacillary angiomatosis, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Cryptosporidiosis is an AIDS-defining condition that manifests with chronic, watery diarrhea as well as nausea and abdominal pain. Liver involvement (e.g., hepatitis) does occur in some cases, but cutaneous lesions are not characteristic of this condition.

HHV-8 virus infection causes Kaposi sarcoma (KS), an AIDS-defining condition that manifests with solitary or multiple bluish-brown, painless plaques or nodules. With disease progression, KS may disseminate to other organs (e.g., the liver). However, in addition to vascular proliferation, biopsy findings would also show spindle-shaped cells. Moreover, a biopsy sample in a patient with KS typically shows abundant lymphocytes, not neutrophils.

Treponema pallidum infection causes syphilis. Patients with secondary syphilis may present with nodular lesions. However, vascular proliferation is not a typical histopathological finding and the patient has tested negative for rapid plasma reagin (RPR), which together make syphilis an unlikely diagnosis.

Localized Candida infection causes several conditions, including oral thrush, skin infections, Candida esophagitis (an AIDS-defining condition), and invasive disease (systemic candidiasis). Systemic infection can occasionally involve the liver. However, vascular proliferation and abundant neutrophils would not be expected on biopsy.

Infection with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), an AIDS-defining condition, is the most common opportunistic bacterial infection in patients with AIDS. However, MAC typically causes systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy) and very rarely manifests in patients with a CD4+ count > 50/mm^3.

Bartonella henselae infection causes bacillary angiomatosis, which primarily occurs in patients who are severely immunocompromised (especially those with AIDS and a CD4 count < 100/mm^3). Bacillary angiomatosis typically manifests with solitary or multiple cutaneous papules and nodules that are red, flesh-colored, or colorless and bleed easily. Visceral organ involvement, which is uncommon, can manifest with abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed if a biopsy of the affected tissue shows vascular proliferation and neutrophilic infiltrate and positivity on Warthin-Starry staining. Treatment is antibiotic therapy (erythromycin or doxycycline).

question_text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of low-grade fever, muscle aches, and a rash. She has had 4 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the skin examination shows no abnormalities. There are no lesions in the oral or genital mucosa. Testing for nonspecific anticardiolipin antibodies is positive. An antinuclear antibody test is negative. It is most appropriate for the physician to order which of the following tests at this time?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of low-grade fever, muscle aches, and a rash. She has had 4 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the skin examination shows no abnormalities. There are no lesions in the oral or genital mucosa. Testing for nonspecific anticardiolipin antibodies is positive. An antinuclear antibody test is negative. It is most appropriate for the physician to order which of the following tests at this time?
hint: The presence of nonspecific anticardiolipin antibodies is assessed with the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test (VDRL), which is a nontreponemal test (NTT). In addition to the positive VDRL, this patient has a low-grade fever, myalgias, and a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles, all of which suggest secondary syphilis.
learning_objective: Recognize secondary syphilis, and choose the most appropriate confirmatory test.

answers.explanation_why: Serum C3 and/or C4 levels are decreased in patients with active systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and complement levels are used to monitor for disease activity. A low-grade fever, muscle aches, a positive anticardiolipin test, and a rash in a young woman raise concerns for SLE. However, a negative antinuclear antibody test (ANA) makes SLE unlikely. A maculopapular rash that involves the palms and soles in a patient with high-risk sexual behavior is more suggestive of syphilis, in which serum complement levels typically remain normal.

Although bacterial cultures are used to detect a wide variety of pathogens, they cannot be used in the diagnosis of syphilis. Treponema are obligate intracellular organisms that can only survive in mammalian cells and cannot be cultured in the laboratory.

Flow cytometry is used for the workup of hematologic diseases (e.g., leukemia, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria) and immunodeficiencies (e.g., quantification of CD4+ T cells in patients with confirmed HIV infection). Screening for HIV infection using a combination HIV antibody with HIV antigen test should be performed in patients with confirmed syphilis but flow cytometry is not used in the workup of syphilis.

Darkfield microscopy using a wet mount from certain mucocutaneous lesions can directly visualize the Treponema pallidum spirochete and confirm syphilis. However, T. pallidum is only present in infectious syphilitic lesions such as the chancre of primary syphilis and condylomata lata of secondary syphilis. Condylomata lata are broad-based, wart-like lesions typically present in the anogenital folds, oral mucosa, and intertriginous areas. The polymorphic disseminated rash of secondary syphilis is the result of an immunologic reaction and a wet mount from this rash would not contain T. pallidum.

The fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is a treponemal test (TT). The diagnosis of syphilis is confirmed using a serial testing strategy. In the standard testing algorithm, an NTT (e.g., VDRL, plasma reagin test) is performed first. If the result is positive or equivocal, a TT is performed. In the reverse testing algorithm, a TT is performed first, followed by an NTT test. A positive result for both tests strongly supports the diagnosis of syphilis. Because treponemal tests usually remain positive regardless of treatment or disease activity, a positive FTA-ABS indicates either active syphilis infection or persistent antibodies from a prior infection.

images.title: Syphilis serological testing algorithm
images.description:
FTA-ABS: fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption
NTT: nontreponemal test
RPR: rapid plasma reagin
TPPA: treponema pallidum particle agglutination
TT: treponemal test
VDRL: venereal disease research laboratory

question_text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of sharp, shooting pain in both legs. Twenty years ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved without treatment. He has no history of serious illness. Examination shows small pupils that constrict with accommodation but do not react to light. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the distal lower extremities. Patellar reflexes are absent bilaterally. His gait is unsteady and broad-based. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of sharp, shooting pain in both legs. Twenty years ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved without treatment. He has no history of serious illness. Examination shows small pupils that constrict with accommodation but do not react to light. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the distal lower extremities. Patellar reflexes are absent bilaterally. His gait is unsteady and broad-based. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
hint: This patient has evidence of tabes dorsalis (ataxia, lower extremity pain, impaired sensation in the lower extremities) and Argyll Robertson pupil (impaired pupillary constriction), suggesting tertiary syphilis.
learning_objective: Recognize tertiary syphilis, and recall its cardiovascular complications.

answers.explanation_why: Development of atrioventricular block can be caused by various etiologies (e.g., infection, cardiomyopathy, ischemia); the most common infectious causes include Lyme disease and infective endocarditis (IE). This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing atrioventricular block.

Mitral valve regurgitation is a potential complication of rheumatic fever (RF) or rheumatic heart disease (due to untreated RF). RF can also manifest with neurological sequelae (e.g., Sydenham chorea); however, paresthesia and pupillary involvement would not be expected. This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing mitral valve regurgitation.

Penile squamous cell carcinoma is associated with infection from high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (i.e., HPV-16, HPV-18). Anogenital lesions caused by HPV are usually raised, cauliflower-like, and exophytic, rather than the painless ulcers reported by this patient. This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

Cerebral artery septic embolism is almost exclusively seen in left-sided infective endocarditis, especially with Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus bovis infection, and can lead to the development of mycotic aneurysm. This patient has evidence of syphilis infection, which is not known to cause embolization.

Inflammatory polyarthritis can occur in patients with disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) or reactive arthritis, but not syphilis infection. While synovitis can develop in patients with syphilis, it is more typically seen in secondary syphilis, and would classically manifest within 10 weeks of primary infection; this patient's infection has been present for much longer.

In addition to tabes dorsalis and Argyll Robertson pupil, patients with tertiary syphilis are at risk of developing thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) from aortitis. Treponemal-mediated destruction of the vasa vasorum classically affects the ascending aorta and can also lead to aortic root dilatation and aortic regurgitation. These cardiovascular complications are late manifestations of syphilis, and typically only occur after 15 years of untreated infection.

question_text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and fluid release from painful lumps in the right groin. He had an atraumatic ulceration of the penis about 1 month ago that was not painful and resolved on its own within 1 week. He works at an animal shelter for abandoned pets. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and does not use condoms. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination of the groin shows numerous, tender nodules with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
content_preview: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and fluid release from painful lumps in the right groin. He had an atraumatic ulceration of the penis about 1 month ago that was not painful and resolved on its own within 1 week. He works at an animal shelter for abandoned pets. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and does not use condoms. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination of the groin shows numerous, tender nodules with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
hint: A painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–4 weeks after the initial lesion has healed is consistent with a diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum.
learning_objective: Recognize lymphogranuloma venereum, and recall its causal pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease (CSD), which can manifest with fever, general malaise, and tender, suppurative lymphadenopathy. This patient's history of working at an animal shelter puts him at risk for exposure to Bartonella henselae. However, CSD typically manifests with papules and/or pustules at the cutaneous site of inoculation, which is most commonly in the limbs. This patient's penile lesion and sexual history make a different causative pathogen more likely.

images.title: Cat scratch disease
images.description: A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

answers.explanation_why: Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. Primary syphilis manifests with a painless, genital ulcer (chancre) and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient's lesions, the inguinal lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis is nonsuppurative, occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance, and is not accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). Moreover, the genital ulcer usually resolves within 3–6 weeks without treatment (rather than 1 week).

images.title: Chancre of the glans penis in primary syphilis
images.description: A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2) can cause genital ulcers, fever, and tender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, HSV-2 usually causes multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers and nonsuppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. In contrast to this patient's initial ulcer, these lesions do not spontaneously resolve.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why: The serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum, the incidence of which is increased in men who have sex with men. Further manifestations include systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, chills, and/or myalgia. Lymphogranuloma venereum is treated with doxycycline or macrolides such as erythromycin. Without antibiotic treatment, lymphogranuloma venereum can cause chronic genital lymphedema, strictures in the anogenital tract, and/or infertility.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum
images.description: Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which causes painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient, who has a history of a self-resolving, painless genital ulcer, chancroid causes painful genital ulcers with yellow-gray exudates. Systemic manifestations, such as fever, are uncommon.

images.title: Chancroid lesion on the penis
images.description: There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

answers.explanation_why: Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which can initially manifest with painless, suppurative genital lesions. However, these lesions are typically beefy-red, bleed easily (due to their hypervascularity), spread and destroy surrounding tissue, and do not resolve spontaneously without treatment. Regional lymphadenopathy and fever are generally absent, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infectionMultiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

question_text: A 20-year-old male comes to the physician because of a 1-week-history of a painless ulceration on his penis. The patient is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use barrier protection. Physical examination shows a shallow, firm ulcer with a smooth base along the shaft of the penis and nontender bilateral inguinal adenopathy. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 20-year-old male comes to the physician because of a 1-week-history of a painless ulceration on his penis. The patient is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use barrier protection. Physical examination shows a shallow, firm ulcer with a smooth base along the shaft of the penis and nontender bilateral inguinal adenopathy. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
hint: This patient's solitary, nontender, ulcerated lesion with indurated borders (chancre) located on the penis indicates early primary syphilis, which is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochetal organism.
learning_objective: Recognize primary syphilis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Although blood cultures are effective diagnostic methods in several infectious diseases, T. pallidum cannot be cultured.

A Tzanck test can be used to diagnose skin lesions resulting from herpes virus infections such as HSV1, varicella zoster, or cytomegalovirus infection. A Tzanck smear has no role in the early diagnosis of syphilis and would be negative in this patient.
Although swab cultures are effective diagnostic methods in several infectious diseases, T. pallidum cannot be cultured.

PCR can be used to directly detect a pathogen by specifically amplifying its DNA or RNA. Although PCR from urine samples is used to diagnose several sexually transmitted diseases (e.g., gonorrhea, Chlamydia trachomatis infection), a PCR for syphilis requires samples from the ulcer itself. Therefore, a solitary PCR from this patient's urine would not be helpful in confirming the diagnosis, and likely yield a negative result.

Darkfield microscopy is a diagnostic method that allows direct visualization of T. pallidum from the lesion's serous exudate. This confirms the diagnosis without the use of a screening serologic test, which have a high false-negative rate in early primary syphilis.

Serologic screening tests for syphilis include treponemal tests, which detect antibodies against antigens from T. pallidum (e.g., fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test), and non-treponemal tests, which detect antibodies against cellular damage caused by the bacteria (e.g., rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test). Nontreponemal tests are nonspecific and often used as a first screen. Treponemal tests are then used if the nontreponemal tests yield positive or equivocal results. However, in early primary syphilis, as seen in this patient, all serologic tests have a high false-negative rate and are therefore not suitable for early confirmation of the diagnosis.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual pelvic examination and Pap smear. Her last Pap smear was 3 years ago. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners and takes an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. A photomicrograph of cervical cells from the Pap smear specimen is shown. Cells similar to the one indicated by the arrow are most likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?

She has been sexually active with multiple male partners and takes an oral contraceptive. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. A photomicrograph of cervical cells from the Pap smear specimen is shown. Cells similar to the one indicated by the arrow are most likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
hint: The cell indicated by the arrow is a dysplastic squamous epithelial cell with a perinuclear halo, an enlarged, irregular nucleus, and hyperchromasia. These are features of koilocytes. If left untreated, these cells can progress to eventually cause cervical cancer.
learning_objective: Recognize koilocytes on a Pap smear, and recall their association with HPV infection.

answers.explanation_why: Genital herpes is commonly caused by HSV-2 and presents with redness, swelling, tingling, pain, and pruritus of the genitals. Histopathology of herpes virus infection reveals acantholysis and blister cavities, which contain keratinocytes showing features of viral infection (e.g. multinucleation and nuclear inclusions), rather than koilocytes as seen here.

Trichomoniasis is caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis and presents with symptoms of vulvovaginitis and a foul-smelling, foamy, yellow-green, purulent vaginal discharge. Saline wet mount preparation shows motile flagellated protozoa rather than koilocytes, as seen here.

images.title: Trichomonas vaginalis
images.description: Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

answers.explanation_why:
Koilocytes are pathognomonic of infection with human papillomavirus (HPV). Condylomata acuminata, like cervical dysplasia, are caused by an infection with HPV and can therefore present with koilocytes on histopathology. Condylomata acuminata are typically associated with HPV strains 6 and 11. Other manifestations of HPV infection include vulvar and vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, as well as skin warts (verruca vulgaris) and plantar warts.

As this patient's Pap smear is consistent with a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, the next step in management includes testing for high-risk HPV strains (i.e., 16, 18, 31, and 33) via PCR. Depending on the result, this should be followed by colposcopy (positive high-risk HPV status) or repeated cytologic examination (negative high-risk HPV status).

images.title: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata)
images.description: Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, erythematous lesions are visible in the perianal region.

answers.explanation_why: A (painless) genital chancre is seen in primary syphilis, which is caused by infection with Treponema pallidum. Dark-field microscopy of these lesions therefore shows treponemes without any specific cellular changes rather than koilocytes, as in this patient's histopathology.

Vulvovaginal candidiasis is caused by infection with Candida spp. and presents with symptoms of vulvovaginitis and a white lumpy, curd-like discharge. Wet mount preparation with potassium hydroxide (KOH) shows pseudohyphae with budding yeast rather than koilocytes, as seen here.

Bacterial vaginosis is caused by Gardnerella vaginalis and presents with increased, sometimes gray-colored vaginal discharge and a characteristically fishy odor. Wet mount preparation reveals presence of clue cells rather than koilocytes, as seen in this patient's photomicrograph.

images.title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

images.title: Pap smear showing low-grade dysplasia
images.description: Photomicrograph of a cervical pap smear (Papanicolaou stain; high magnification)Normal superficial squamous cells (pink cytoplasm, examples indicated by dashed outlines) and some intermediate squamous cells (example indicated by outline) are visible. An irregular clump of koilocytes (indicated by arrow) is visible with the characteristic perinuclear halos (indicated by arrowheads). The koilocytes also show slight nuclear enlargement with irregularly distributed chromatin; binucleation (yellow overlay) is also seen.These are typical features of a low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL).

question_text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 3 days. She has been sexually active with three male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Physical exam shows thin grayish-white vaginal discharge. There is no erythema of the vaginal mucosa. The pH of the discharge is 5.9. Adding potassium hydroxide (KOH) to a mount containing vaginal discharge produces a fishy odor. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 3 days. She has been sexually active with three male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Physical exam shows thin grayish-white vaginal discharge. There is no erythema of the vaginal mucosa. The pH of the discharge is 5.9. Adding potassium hydroxide (KOH) to a mount containing vaginal discharge produces a fishy odor. Further evaluation of this patient's vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Clue cells are an important histological finding for this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize bacterial vaginosis, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Chlamydia trachomatis is a gram-negative, obligate intracellular bacterium that causes chlamydia, the most common sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. While many cases are asymptomatic, chlamydia can present with an odorless and purulent cervical discharge; cervical friability; and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding. Although this patient has risk factors for chlamydia, she has no cervical bleeding during bimanual exam and a different description of vaginal discharge (color, smell, whiff).

Pseudohyphae are a morphological growth form of yeast. When associated with gynecological complaints, pseudohyphae typically refer to Candida albicans, which causes vulvovaginal candidiasis. The main features of vulvovaginal candidiasis are dyspareunia, vaginal pruritus, and odorless vaginal discharge resembling cottage cheese with normal pH (4–4.5). This patient is unlikely to have vaginal candidiasis because her discharge is grayish-white and malodorous, and she has an increased pH.

images.title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
images.description: Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.White circles: examples of budding yeast

answers.explanation_why: Gardnerella vaginalis is a pleomorphic, gram-variable rod that causes bacterial vaginosis, which is consistent with this patient's findings of characteristic thin grayish-white vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5 that has a fishy odor when KOH is added (positive whiff-amine test). The absence of vaginal pain or erythema further supports this diagnosis. Bacterial vaginosis typically develops when the pH of the vagina rises above 4.5, which allows G. vaginalis to multiply and results in the characteristic malodorous vaginal discharge. Predisposing factors include a shift in vaginal flora (e.g., douching decreases Lactobacillus that maintain vaginal pH between 3.8 and 4.5), the release of amines from increased bacterial degradation of proteins, and/or increased sexual activity (as the pH of semen is between 7.2 and 7.8).

images.title: Clue cells in bacterial vaginosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a vaginal smear specimen (vaginal wet mount; medium power magnification)Squamous cells with a stippled appearance and fuzzy borders can be seen (clue cells) due to bacteria adhering to the cell surface.The presence of clue cells is one of the four Amsel criteria (besides thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge; vaginal fluid pH of > 4.5; and a fishy odor after adding 10% potassium hydroxide solution to wet mount) for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. Gardnerella vaginalis is the most common cause of this condition.

answers.explanation_why: Treponema pallidum is a spirochete that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis presents as a chancre whereas secondary syphilis manifests with condyloma lata, lymphadenopathy, and polymorphic rash that classically involves the palms and soles. Although this patient has risk factors for syphilis, syphilis cannot explain her abnormal vaginal discharge.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus that causes gonorrhea, a common sexually transmitted disease. While gonorrhea is usually asymptomatic in women, it can manifest as purulent vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding. Although this patient has risk factors for gonorrhea, she has a different vaginal discharge description (odorless, creamy, pale with negative Whiff test).

Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile, and flagellated protozoan that causes trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis presents with foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Although this patient has malodorous vaginal discharge with increased vaginal pH, the vaginal discharge associated with trichomoniasis has different characteristics than that of this patient. Furthermore, the wet mount would show motile, flagellated organisms in trichomoniasis.

question_text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician with throbbing right scrotal pain for 1 day. He has also had a burning sensation on urination during the last 4 days. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and does not use condoms. Physical examination shows a tender, palpable swelling on the upper pole of the right testicle; lifting the testicle relieves the pain. A Gram stain of urethral secretions shows numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician with throbbing right scrotal pain for 1 day. He has also had a burning sensation on urination during the last 4 days. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and does not use condoms. Physical examination shows a tender, palpable swelling on the upper pole of the right testicle; lifting the testicle relieves the pain. A Gram stain of urethral secretions shows numerous polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This young man, who engages in high-risk sexual behavior, has dysuria, a tender swelling on the right testicle, and a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), indicating epididymitis.
learning_objective: Recognize epididymitis in a young man, and recall its common pathogens.

answers.explanation_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a very common cause of epididymitis in men below the age of 35 years. It causes pain and swelling of the testis and a positive Prehn sign. However, Gram stain would show gram-negative, aerobic, facultative intracellular diplococci.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa can cause urinary tract infection, which again can lead to epididymitis. However, this mostly affects prepubertal boys and older males. Additionally, P. aeruginosa would have shown up as a gram-negative, rod-shaped organism on Gram stain.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a nonmotile, aerobic, gram-positive, acid-fast bacillus with a rich lipid cell wall that causes chronic epididymitis (> 6-week course of disease). Symptoms include scrotal pain and swelling. However, compared to acute epididymitis, swelling would be minimal, and there would be a history of recurrent or untreated epididymitis. Also, the patient has no risk factors for TB like immunosuppression, drug or alcohol abuse, or travel to a region with higher rates.

Treponema pallidum is a rare cause of epididymitis and it is most known for causing syphilis. This patient does exhibit high-risk sexual behavior, making STD very likely. Furthermore, T. pallidum would not show up on Gram stain. However, this patient does not have any findings indicative of syphilis such as a painless lesion on the penile shaft, and since T. pallidum is a rare cause of epididymitis, a different pathogen is more likely.

Mumps virus would cause orchitis, which would present with inflammation of one or both testes, causing pain and swelling of testis without an identifiable organism on Gram stain. However, it would also present with sudden onset of fever, nausea, vomiting, and signs of parotitis (cheek pain and swelling). In addition, peak incidence would be between 5–14 years of age.

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. It can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Because coinfection is common, empiric treatment of acute epididymitis in this patient involves ceftriaxone and doxycycline to cover both pathogens.

Staphylococcus aureus might cause folliculitis, a localized inflammation of the hair follicle or sebaceous glands that is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. Infection can occur due to shaving, causing local pain and swelling. However, Gram stain would show a gram-positive and coagulase-positive coccus and negative Prehn sign.

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of urinary tract infection, which can lead to epididymitis. However, this mostly affects prepubertal boys and older males. Another cause is much more likely in this young, sexually active male.
