question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a growth on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago. He has been divorced for 25 years and has had “at least 30 sexual partners” since. Physical examination shows a nontender 2.5-cm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is firm left inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the lesion shows atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathogens?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a growth on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago. He has been divorced for 25 years and has had “at least 30 sexual partners” since. Physical examination shows a nontender 2.5-cm ulcerated lesion with an erythematous base on the dorsum of the glans. There is firm left inguinal lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the lesion shows atypical squamous cells with varying degrees of mitotic activity. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following pathogens?
hint: This patient most likely has carcinoma of the penis.
learning_objective: Recognize carcinoma of the penis, and recall its association with specific pathogens.

answers.explanation_why:
Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly with types 16 and 18, is a known risk factor for carcinoma of the penis. Other risk factors for carcinoma of the penis include phimosis and HIV infection. Although HIV may directly contribute to carcinogenesis, this association may also be due to the frequent HPV co-infection in this patient group. Apart from the immunosuppression enabling the persistence of HPV infection, HIV also seems to directly promote HPV-associated carcinogenesis.

High-risk types of HPV (i.e., 16, 18, 31, 33) are also associated with cervical cancer (almost all cases), as well as anal, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

EBV is associated with several malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. However, EBV is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

HSV-2 is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes genital herpes. Unlike this patient's slowly increasing painless ulcer, genital herpes typically manifests with multiple painful lesions that evolve from vesicles and pustules to ulcers over about 10 days. Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy is common. HSV-2 is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: Penile shaft and glansTwo ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

answers.explanation_why: H. ducreyi is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes chancroid. Unlike this patient's presentation, chancroid typically manifests with erythematous papules that become pustular and erode into very painful genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. H. ducreyi is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

N. gonorrhoeae is a sexually transmitted pathogen and a common cause of genitourinary infections such as urethritis and epididymitis. None of these infections would cause a gradually increasing ulcerated lesion on the penis. Moreover, they are associated with symptoms such as purulent urethral discharge and dysuria (if urethritis), or scrotal pain and swelling (if epididymitis). N. gonorrhoeae is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

T. pallidum is a sexually transmitted pathogen that causes syphilis. Primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, painless ulcer in the genital region (chancre) as well as regional nontender lymphadenopathy. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals spontaneously within 3–6 weeks. Systemic symptoms due to secondary syphilis are expected 3–4 months after primary infection. T. pallidum is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

C. trachomatis is a sexually transmitted pathogen whose serotypes L1–L3 can cause lymphogranuloma venereum. This condition initially manifests with a small, painless ulcer in the genital region. However, the ulcer does not increase gradually but typically heals and disappears within one week. After 2–6 weeks, the extension of the infection to the draining lymph nodes results in painful, suppurative, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). C. trachomatis is not associated with carcinoma of the penis.

question_text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of severe itching in the area of her genitals. She reports that the itching is most severe at night. She has been sexually active with three partners over the past year; she uses condoms for contraception. Her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms. Pelvic examination shows vulvar excoriations. A photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of severe itching in the area of her genitals. She reports that the itching is most severe at night. She has been sexually active with three partners over the past year; she uses condoms for contraception. Her current sexual partner is experiencing similar symptoms. Pelvic examination shows vulvar excoriations. A photomicrograph of an epilated pubic hair is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: The photomicrograph shows a nit attached to the hair shaft.
learning_objective: Recognize pediculosis pubis, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Infestation with the parasite Phthirus pubis causes pediculosis pubis, an infection that manifests with anogenital pruritus. Pediculosis pubis is a sexually transmitted infection that is not prevented by condoms. Physical examination of the pubic area typically shows excoriations as well as lice, their nits, and their droppings, which are visible both with the naked eye and on microscopy, as seen in the photomicrograph here.

Infestation with Pediculus humanus causes pediculosis capitis or pediculosis corporis, which also manifest with pruritus and excoriations. However, this patient's signs and symptoms are limited to the genital area, making a head or body lice infestation unlikely. Additionally, nits of Pediculus humanus corporis attach to clothes and nits of Pediculus humanus capitis attach to scalp hair shafts, whereas the photomicrograph here shows a nit attached to a pubic hair.

The roundworm Enterobius vermicularis causes enterobiasis, which may also manifest with anogenital pruritus that is most severe at night. Eggs are transmitted through the fecal-oral route, typically via contaminated hands or during sexual intercourse, which is why close contacts of infected patients are often also affected. However, this patient's photomicrograph shows a nit attached to a shaft of a pubic hair, which is not typical for E. vermicularis. Enterobiasis is instead diagnosed through direct visualization of mobile worms in the perianal region or with a positive tape test, in which eggs of the worm are visible.

images.title: Enterobiasis
images.description: Two pinworms (Enterobius vermicularis) in a stool sample.

answers.explanation_why: Dermatophytes like Epidermophyton floccosum cause diseases such as tinea pedis, tinea cruris, tinea corporis, and onychomycosis. While tinea cruris can manifest with pruritus and excoriations in the genital area, typical skin findings include an area of centrifugally growing, circular erythema, which is not described in this patient. Additionally, dermatophyte infections will show hyphae on microscopy, while the photomicrograph here shows an organism attached to a pubic hair.

images.title: Tinea cruris
images.description: There is well-demarcated erythema with a raised border visible around the scrotum and upper thighs of the patient.

answers.explanation_why: Infestation with Sarcoptes scabiei causes scabies, a highly contagious infection transmitted through skin-to-skin contact (e.g., sexual intercourse). Although typical findings include pruritus and excoriations, scabies most commonly manifests with papules, vesicles, and burrow tracks on the wrists and intertriginous regions rather than the genital area. Furthermore, unlike the organism seen in the photomicrograph here, Sarcoptes scabiei mites do not attach to pubic hair.

images.title: Scabies mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a human itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis)Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, the mite that causes scabies, has a round body and four pairs of legs (green overlay): The front legs end in suckers, while the hind legs end in long bristles. Between the medial front legs, the scabies mite has a mouthpart (red overlay) that it uses for burrowing into the host's skin. Between the medial posterior pairs of legs, the anus of the mite is visible (yellow overlay), from which the female mites lay eggs in the skin's stratum corneum.

images.title: Nit of a pubic louse
images.description: Pubic lice attach their nits (louse eggs) to human pubic hair using a sticky secretion.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of burning pain during urination for the past week. During this period, he has also had clear discharge from the penis. He recently had unprotected sex with his girlfriend, who is the same age as him. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. The patient says that his girlfriend knows about his symptoms, but he does not want his parents to be notified of his sexual activity or his positive test for a sexually transmitted infection because they do not approve of premarital sex. He adds that he wants to avoid any further conflicts with his mother, as they have been fighting recently. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of burning pain during urination for the past week. During this period, he has also had clear discharge from the penis. He recently had unprotected sex with his girlfriend, who is the same age as him. The result of a polymerase chain reaction test for Chlamydia trachomatis is positive. The patient says that his girlfriend knows about his symptoms, but he does not want his parents to be notified of his sexual activity or his positive test for a sexually transmitted infection because they do not approve of premarital sex. He adds that he wants to avoid any further conflicts with his mother, as they have been fighting recently. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?
hint: There are exceptions to when consent from a parent is required before treating a minor.
learning_objective: Recognize when minors can consent to STI treatment without parental notification.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient and inform the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient’s parents give consent to treatment
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Thus, informing this patient's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality, and their consent to treatment is not needed.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's parents and his girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient only if the patient meets the criteria for legal emancipation
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); legal emancipation is not required.

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient without notifying the patient’s parents or the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why:
Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential (though minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, because this patient has a notifiable disease (Chlamydia trachomatis infection), the physician is required to report the case to a public health official.

Other exceptions to when parental consent is generally not needed for a minor to receive medical care include emergency care, care related to addiction, and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., contraception, pregnancy).

answers.content: Prescribe medication for the patient and his girlfriend and inform both the patient’s parents and the girlfriend’s parents
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs); parental consent is not required. Thus, informing this patient's parents and his girlfriend's parents without his consent is a breach of confidentiality. In several states, physicians can also prescribe treatment for certain sexually transmitted infections for a patient's partner even if the partner has not been evaluated by the physician.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of urinary frequency, pelvic discomfort, and burning with urination for the past 7 days. She has been sexually active with 3 male partners over the past 6 months and usually uses condoms for contraception. One year ago, she was treated for a genital herpes simplex infection. She has a history of chronic ear infections and asthma. Her only medication is a combined fluticasone-albuterol inhaler. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks alcohol socially up to 4 times per week. Her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows normal-appearing external genitalia. Erythema and sparse discharge are present at the urethral meatus. On bimanual examination, the uterus is mobile, and there is no cervical motion tenderness. A Gram stain of the patient's urethral swab is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of urinary frequency, pelvic discomfort, and burning with urination for the past 7 days. She has been sexually active with 3 male partners over the past 6 months and usually uses condoms for contraception. One year ago, she was treated for a genital herpes simplex infection. She has a history of chronic ear infections and asthma. Her only medication is a combined fluticasone-albuterol inhaler. She does not smoke cigarettes and drinks alcohol socially up to 4 times per week. Her temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows normal-appearing external genitalia. Erythema and sparse discharge are present at the urethral meatus. On bimanual examination, the uterus is mobile, and there is no cervical motion tenderness. A Gram stain of the patient's urethral swab is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Gram stain of the patient's urethral swab shows gram-negative, intracellular diplococci.
learning_objective: Recognize gonorrhea by identifying gram-negative, intracellular diplococci on Gram stain.

answers.explanation_why: Vaginal thrush, caused by Candida, is a fungal infection that can manifest with dysuria. However, this patient does not have other typical features of vaginal thrush, including white, cottage cheese-like vaginal discharge, vulvovaginal erythema, pruritus, and dyspareunia. In addition, the diagnosis of vaginal thrush is made with wet mount microscopy with KOH staining that shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae.

images.title: Pseudohyphae in vulvovaginal candidiasis
images.description: Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.White circles: examples of budding yeast

answers.explanation_why: Chlamydia trachomatis urethritis is a common sexually-transmitted infection that manifests with urinary frequency, dysuria, and urethral erythema and discharge. However, C. trachomatis, an obligate intracellular bacterium, is not detectable by Gram stain. C. trachomatis may be visible as cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain, but sensitivity is low; a nucleic acid amplification test is the preferred diagnostic test.

Mycoplasma genitalium urethritis is a sexually-transmitted infection that manifests with urinary frequency, dysuria, and urethral erythema and discharge. However, M. genitalium lacks a cell wall and is, therefore, not detectable by Gram stain. M. genitalium is a fastidious bacterial species; a nucleic acid amplification test of a first-void urine sample (for male patients) or vaginal swab (for female patients) is the preferred diagnostic test.

The swab of this patient's urethral discharge shows the presence of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a gram-negative, intracellular diplococcus, which causes gonorrhea. This patient, who lacks the features of pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., fever, abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness), has uncomplicated gonorrhea and should be treated with a single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone. However, because coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis is common and has not been excluded, she should also receive treatment with oral doxycycline for seven days.

Gram stain for Neisseria gonorrhoeae often results in a false negative result. The test of choice for detecting gonorrhea is nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT), which has both high sensitivity and specificity for this condition. The diagnosis of chlamydia is also made with NAAT.

Trichomonas vaginalis urethritis is a sexually-transmitted infection that manifests with urinary frequency, dysuria, and urethral erythema and discharge. However, the diagnosis of trichomoniasis is made with wet mount microscopy that shows motile protozoa.

images.title: Trichomonas vaginalis
images.description: Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.

answers.explanation_why: Escherichia coli cystitis is a common urinary tract infection that manifests with urinary frequency and dysuria. However, it does not typically cause urethral erythema or discharge. In addition, Gram stain of urine specimens obtained from patients infected with E. coli typically shows gram-negative bacilli rather than gram-negative, intracellular diplococci.

In female patients, primary syphilis typically manifests with a solitary, raised, vulvovaginal or anal papule that evolves into a painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders (i.e., chancre) with nontender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. In addition, Treponema pallidum, the causative pathogen of syphilis, does not usually appear on Gram stain.

images.title: Neisseria gonorrhoeae
images.description: Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

question_text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful lesion on his penis. The lesion appeared 2 days ago and has since grown in size. It is draining yellow purulent material. One week ago, he returned from a 1-month trip to Cambodia. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a painful lesion on his penis. The lesion appeared 2 days ago and has since grown in size. It is draining yellow purulent material. One week ago, he returned from a 1-month trip to Cambodia. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is sexually active with multiple female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: This patient's painful and necrotic lesion with purulent discharge as well as tender lymphadenopathy following recent travel to a tropical region (i.e., Cambodia) is suggestive of chancroid.
learning_objective: Recognize chancroid, and recall its causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2, or L3 causes lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). LGV initially manifests with small, painless, shallow genital ulcers that heal spontaneously without scarring. Approx. 2–6 weeks later, patients develop painful suppurative lymphadenopathy that may ulcerate (buboes) and systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise, and chills). This patient's acutely painful lesion, lymphadenopathy, and absence of systemic signs are not characteristic of LGV.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)
images.description: A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which manifests with painless nodules that eventually ulcerate into large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily. Regional lymphadenopathy is usually absent. This patient's acutely painful ulcer and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy make infection with K. granulomatis unlikely.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with Treponema pallidum causes syphilis, which manifests with a solitary painless ulcer with indurated borders (a chancre) and bilateral painless regional lymphadenopathy. This patient's painful ulcer, tender regional lymphadenopathy, and purulent exudate make infection with T. pallidum unlikely.

images.title: Chancre of penis (primary syphilis)
images.description:
Localization: proximal penile shaft
Description: painless, superficial ulcer with indurated borders
Diagnosis: chancre of primary syphilis

answers.explanation_why: Infection with HSV (typically HSV2) causes genital herpes, which manifests with painful lymphadenopathy with multiple grouped painful vesicles and/or ulcers on or around the genitals. Patients also experience severe genital discomfort (e.g., itching and burning) and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever and malaise). This patient's solitary ulcer, purulent exudate, and lack of vesicles make HSV infection unlikely.

images.title: Genital herpes
images.description: Penile shaft and glansTwo ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

answers.explanation_why: Infection with Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which typically manifests with an intensely painful, clearly demarcated lesion with a grey necrotic base and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. Men usually present with a single lesion, while women often develop multiple synchronous lesions. H. ducreyi is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions (e.g., Cambodia) and rare in the United States. Chancroid is usually treated with a single dose of oral azithromycin or intramuscular ceftriaxone.

Infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea, which is usually asymptomatic but can manifest with urethritis or epididymitis in men. Urethritis manifests with painful urination and spontaneous mucopurulent discharge from the urethral meatus, while epididymitis manifests with acute, painful, unilateral scrotal swelling. None of these symptoms are present in this patient. In addition, N. gonorrhoeae infection does not explain this patient's painful exudative ulcer or tender lymphadenopathy.

images.title: Chancroid lesion on the penis
images.description: There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of lesions on her vulva. She has no pain or discharge from the lesions but she has noticed some bloody spots in her underwear. For the past year, she has been traveling around India, Australia, South Africa, and the Caribbean while working as a blogger. During this time, she has had unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. Examination shows 4 nontender indurated ulcers on her labia minora that have a red base and raised, rolled margins; the ulcers are up to 8 mm in size. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A Giemsa-stained smear of one of the ulcers shows oval bodies within macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of lesions on her vulva. She has no pain or discharge from the lesions but she has noticed some bloody spots in her underwear. For the past year, she has been traveling around India, Australia, South Africa, and the Caribbean while working as a blogger. During this time, she has had unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. Examination shows 4 nontender indurated ulcers on her labia minora that have a red base and raised, rolled margins; the ulcers are up to 8 mm in size. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. A Giemsa-stained smear of one of the ulcers shows oval bodies within macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient with high-risk sexual behavior has a sexually transmitted infection caused by a gram-negative, obligate intracellular coccobacillus that multiplies in mononuclear cells (e.g., macrophages) and forms bipolar intracytoplasmic inclusions called Donovan bodies.
learning_objective: Recognize granuloma inguinale (donovanosis).

answers.explanation_why: A syphilitic chancre (caused by Treponema pallidum) manifests as indurated nontender genital ulceration, which is seen here. However, it typically manifests as a single ulcer rather than multiple ulcers and is associated with nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Moreover, a smear of the ulcer would show extracellular spirochetes rather than the intracellular inclusion bodies seen here.

Genital herpes (caused by herpes simplex virus, particularly HSV-2) often manifests as multiple genital ulcers with a red base, like the ones seen here, and a Giemsa-stained smear of the ulcers may show intranuclear bodies (Cowdry A inclusions). However, the ulcers would be painful, nonindurated, have flat margins with an erythematous halo, and be accompanied by tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, unlike the lesions seen in this patient.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why: Lymphogranuloma venereum (caused by L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis) can manifest as painless genital ulceration without inguinal lymphadenopathy because the tender, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy that is characteristic of this condition occurs 2–6 weeks after genital ulceration. Moreover, a Giemsa-stained smear of the ulcer may show intracytoplasmic bodies (reticulate bodies). However, this condition typically causes a single small, shallow, nonindurated ulcer that resolves within a few days whereas this patient has had multiple indurated lesions for the past three weeks.

Chancroid (caused by Haemophilus ducreyi) can manifest as multiple vulvar ulcers, which are seen in this patient. However, these ulcers are typically very painful, nonindurated, and have undermined margins with a grey or yellow purulent base, unlike the lesions seen here. In addition, chancroid is typically accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, which this patient does not have, and a smear of the ulcer would show extracellular chains of coccobacilli rather than intracellular inclusions.

Multiple, painless, indurated genital ulcers with a vascular beefy-red base and elevated, rolled margins along with the absence of inguinal lymphadenopathy suggest granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, a pathogen that is endemic to tropical and subtropical regions. The lesions begin as nodules at the site of inoculation after a highly variable incubation period (median of 50 days) before ulcerating. This infection is treated with azithromycin, or, alternatively, doxycycline.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infectionMultiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

question_text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of groin pain. Yesterday, he noticed painful blebs on his penis, which he has never had before. He does not have dysuria. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are ramipril and metformin. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has no family history of serious illness. He appears ill and uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 134/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally. There are multiple grouped vesicular lesions with underlying erythema on the base of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of groin pain. Yesterday, he noticed painful blebs on his penis, which he has never had before. He does not have dysuria. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are ramipril and metformin. He is sexually active with multiple male and female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He has no family history of serious illness. He appears ill and uncomfortable. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 134/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender inguinal lymphadenopathy bilaterally. There are multiple grouped vesicular lesions with underlying erythema on the base of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: Painful vesicular genital lesions in conjunction with bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy should raise concern for genital herpes infection.
learning_objective: Recognize genital herpes infection, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Serological antibody test differentiates between HSV-1 and HSV-2. This test is not used in active, primary genital herpes infections because patients may present before seroconversion. Serological antibody testing is indicated in patients with a history of genital vesicular lesions who have had a negative real-time PCR or viral culture or who have a sexual partner with a known HSV infection. Furthermore, serologic antibody testing is indicated in pregnant women with an active genital lesion to classify the maternal infection as primary or nonprimary and to determine the HSV subtype, because these criteria are important for the prognostication of vertical transmission to the infant.

Viral culture can confirm HSV infection, especially in the early stages of infection when fresh vesicular lesions are present. Other diagnostic tests include real-time PCR, which is generally the preferred confirmatory diagnostic test when available because it is more sensitive than viral culture. Serum antibody testing is another diagnostic test for HSV infection, but it cannot be used for primary infections because specific antibodies only develop following seroconversion. Tzanck smear is no longer used in the diagnosis of HSV infections because it has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2.

Darkfield microscopy is used to detect Treponema pallidum in primary and secondary syphilis when specimens can be obtained from skin lesions (e.g., primary genital lesion, condyloma). Primary syphilis causes genital lesions that are typically single, painless ulcers with indurated borders rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, patients with primary syphilis develop nontender rather than painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and usually do not have systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.

A pathergy skin test is used in the diagnostic workup for Behcet disease. This condition can cause genital lesions, which are ulcerating rather than vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, Behcet disease typically causes recurrent oral ulcers and can also manifest with involvement of the eyes (uveitis and/or retinal vasculitis) and skin (erythema nodosum, papulopustular lesions, dermatographism).

A Giemsa-stained smear is used to detect Donovan bodies, which are pathognomonic for granuloma inguinale. This condition causes painless genital nodules that eventually ulcerate rather than painful vesicular lesions like the ones seen in this patient. Additionally, granuloma inguinale is not associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms, both of which are seen here.

Giemsa stain also forms part of the process of Tzanck smear, which is an option for rapid diagnosis of HSV infections. However, Tzanck smear has a low sensitivity and specificity and does not differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2. Another study is more appropriate to confirm the diagnosis in this patient.

A perilesional punch biopsy is indicated for the diagnosis of autoimmune blistering disorders such as bullous pemphigoid and pemphigus vulgaris. These conditions can affect the genital area, but they typically cause blisters rather than vesicles. Tender inguinal lymphadenopathy is not expected in patients with these conditions. Finally, isolated genital involvement is uncommon.

question_text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of pain with defecation, anal itching, and blood in the stool. Over the past month, she has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. She has a history of irritable bowel syndrome, HIV infection, and human papillomavirus infection. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Examination of the perianal region shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a tender mass and bright red blood in the anal canal. Anoscopy shows an exophytic, ulcerated, 2.5-cm (1-in) mass that is located just above the anocutaneous line and below the dentate line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of pain with defecation, anal itching, and blood in the stool. Over the past month, she has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. She has a history of irritable bowel syndrome, HIV infection, and human papillomavirus infection. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Examination of the perianal region shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a tender mass and bright red blood in the anal canal. Anoscopy shows an exophytic, ulcerated, 2.5-cm (1-in) mass that is located just above the anocutaneous line and below the dentate line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A history of immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection) and prior human papillomavirus (HPV) infection are major risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal.

answers.explanation_why: A fibroepithelial polyp of the anus can manifest as an exophytic lesion in the perianal region. However, patients are usually asymptomatic. Moreover, fibroepithelial polyps of the anus arise from anal columns at the dentate line rather than near the anocutaneous line.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the anus manifests as an exophytic, bleeding perianal mass. Besides being very rare (the main risk factor for BCC is sun exposure), BCC of the anus arises below rather than above the anocutaneous line. Moreover, although this condition is associated with immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection), it is not associated with HPV infection.

Internal hemorrhoids can manifest with anal pruritus, hematochezia, and a palpable mass on digital rectal examination. Furthermore, in a patient with irritable bowel syndrome, constipation is a common feature and a risk factor for developing hemorrhoids. However, internal hemorrhoids more commonly appear as dilated, purple or blue veins on anoscopy rather than an exophytic ulcerated mass, and, because they arise from the superior hemorrhoidal plexus, they are located above the dentate line rather than the anocutaneous line. Moreover, defecation is usually painless and weight loss is not expected.

Condylomata acuminata of the anus is caused by HPV infection, which this patient has a history of, and can manifest as an exophytic lesion. However, although condylomata acuminata are pruritic, tender, and friable in a small percentage of cases, they are more commonly asymptomatic; weight loss is not expected. Moreover, when present in the anal canal, condylomata acuminata usually appear as small papules rather than large, ulcerated lesions.

Paget disease of the anus can manifest with anal pruritus, pain with defecation, and hematochezia, all of which are seen here. However, besides being extremely rare, this condition usually manifests as well-demarcated erythematous plaques or patches with a white scale rather than a single ulcerated, exophytic lesion.

A history of hematochezia, anal pruritus, painful defecation, and weight loss in a patient with an exophytic, friable, ulcerated mass above the anal verge is suggestive of anal canal cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological type of anal canal cancer and typically arises below the dentate line (see “Characteristics of the anal canal above and below the dentate line” table). Patients must undergo a biopsy of the tumor to confirm the diagnosis. Women diagnosed with anal canal squamous cell carcinoma should also undergo a gynecological examination for cervical cancer screening.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of multiple painless bumps on the vulva. The bumps are mildly itchy; one of the bumps has bled before when she tried to pull on it. She does not have urinary symptoms or changes in bowel movements. She denies dyspareunia. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Last year, she was treated for a chlamydia infection. She does not smoke cigarettes but occasionally smokes marijuana. She works for a financial startup. Her only medication is an over-the-counter vitamin supplement. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the genital area is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of multiple painless bumps on the vulva. The bumps are mildly itchy; one of the bumps has bled before when she tried to pull on it. She does not have urinary symptoms or changes in bowel movements. She denies dyspareunia. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Last year, she was treated for a chlamydia infection. She does not smoke cigarettes but occasionally smokes marijuana. She works for a financial startup. Her only medication is an over-the-counter vitamin supplement. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the genital area is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The lesions would turn white upon the application of dilute acetic acid.
learning_objective: Recognize condylomata acuminata.

answers.explanation_why: Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a localized infection of the skin caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. MC most commonly affects young children but can manifest in adults with nontender lesions in the genital region. However, the lesions of MC are typically discrete, pearly, dome-shaped, and smooth, with central umbilication; MC does not cause exophytic and cauliflower-like masses. Although large, widespread lesions can develop in individuals who are immunocompromised, this patient has a negative HIV test.

images.title: Molluscum contagiosum
images.description: Photograph of the left anterior thigh of a young girlSeveral skin-colored papules with central umbilication can be seen.These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum.

answers.explanation_why: Squamous cell carcinoma accounts for > 80% of cases of vulvar cancer. However, this condition typically manifests with ulcerating masses and leukoplakia, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses.

images.title: Vulvar squamous cell carcinoma
images.description: The labia minora and majora are difficult to identify due to the destructive, ulcerative, and exophytic growth of the tumor. The affected region shows a livid discoloration with bloody lesions.These findings are suggestive of a squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy.

answers.explanation_why: Genital herpes is mainly caused by HSV-2 and can manifest with skin lesions in the anogenital region. However, the lesions of genital herpes are typically painful, erythematous papules and fluid-filled vesicles that ulcerate, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses. Genital herpes also often results in painful lymphadenopathy in the groin area, which this patient does not have.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

answers.explanation_why: Condylomata acuminata (anogenital warts) are caused by sexually transmitted human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 in most cases. The lesions typically manifest on the vulva, penis, or perianal region and are often exophytic and cauliflower-like, although they can also have a flat or pedunculated appearance. Condylomata acuminata are usually asymptomatic but may cause bleeding and be painful and/or pruritic. There are several treatment options, including local cytostatic treatment (e.g., trichloroacetic acid, podofilox), immune response modifiers (e.g., imiquimod), cryotherapy, and, for more severe cases, curettage, laser surgery, and electrocoagulation. The rate of recurrence is high.

Bowenoid papulosis is a rare, premalignant, focal epidermal dysplasia caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection (most commonly HPV type 16). This condition typically manifests as multiple, flat, red-brown pigmented papules on the external genitals, not exophytic and cauliflower-like masses.

images.title: Bowenoid papulosis
images.description: Labia majora of an immunocompetent patient with an infiltrative and eroded tumor (arrow)Multiple flat and hyperpigmented patches are disseminated over the patient's upper labia majora.These patches suggest Bowenoid papulosis, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

answers.explanation_why: Condylomata lata are painless skin lesions in the anogenital region that occur in secondary syphilis. However, condylomata lata are typically broad-based, smooth, papular erosions, not exophytic, and cauliflower-like masses. Moreover, secondary syphilis typically causes generalized lymphadenopathy and constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue), which this patient does not have.

images.title: Condylomata lata in secondary syphilis
images.description: Broad-based papular erosions are visible around this patient's anus.Clustering around the anus and the typical appearance are suggestive of condylomata lata, a sign of secondary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that classically manifests with pruritic, planar (flat-topped), polygonal, purple papules, and plaques (the 6 Ps of lichen planus) in individuals 30–60 years of age. This condition usually involves the extremities but may also affect the genitals. Although this patient's lesions are mildly pruritic, they do not have the classic morphologic features of lichen planus. Moreover, genital lichen planus typically leads to dyspareunia.

images.title: Condylomata acuminata
images.description: Confluent nodular, verrucous “cauliflower-like” lesions are visible on the entire labia and the anogenital region.These findings are characteristic of Condylomata acuminata, which are mostly caused by infection with HPV types 6 and 11.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of frequent and painful urination and urethral discharge. He has not had scrotal pain or swelling. He has no history of similar symptoms. He is sexually active with one male partner, who is the same age, and uses condoms inconsistently. He is in his junior year at a local high school and lives with his parents and his older sister. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows yellow-green urethral discharge. The testes are symmetrical without tenderness or masses. A diagnosis of gonococcal infection is made. The patient requests treatment. The physician informs the patient that antibiotic therapy will be necessary. He encourages the patient to talk to his parents, but the patient says that he does not wish to inform them about the infection. When the physician asks the patient about his reasons for not wanting to do so, the patient says “They don't even know about my boyfriend and would be extremely angry if they found out. Would you be able to prescribe me antibiotics without informing my parents?” Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: In the United States, adolescents are able to provide consent for the treatment of sexually transmitted infections (STIs).
learning_objective: Recognize adolescents' rights to consent for STI treatment and confidentiality, and choose the appropriate management for gonococcal infection.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but they can still legally request records about your diagnosis."
answers.explanation_why: This patient's information is confidential and should not be shared with his parents unless he gives consent. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents only if you are legally emancipated."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; legal emancipation is not required.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, but I am obligated to inform your partner of your diagnosis."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs; parental consent is not required. Furthermore, all individuals who have had sexual contact with patients diagnosed with Neisseria gonorrhea in the 60 days preceding the diagnosis should be evaluated and treated. However, these individuals should be notified via a public health official or by the index patient, not by the physician. In most states, expedited partner therapy for gonococcal infection treatment is allowed to facilitate partner management and prevent further infection.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics only if one of your parents consents."
answers.explanation_why: Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of STIs. Thus, parental consent is not required. Informing this patient's parents without his consent would constitute a breach of confidentiality.

answers.content: "I can prescribe you antibiotics without informing your parents, and I recommend that your partner get tested."
answers.explanation_why:
Laws regarding consent in adolescent health care differ by state, but all states allow minors to consent to the evaluation and management of addiction and care related to sexual behavior (e.g., STIs, contraception, pregnancy); parental consent is not required. This patient does not want his parents to know that he is sexually active or has an STI. Accordingly, the physician is ethically and legally obliged to keep his medical information confidential from his parents (although minors should, in general, be counseled to have open discussions about health with their parents or legal guardians). However, since Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection is a reportable disease, the physician is required to report the case to a public health official. Ideally, all of the patient's sexual partners within the past 60 days should be informed (either by the patient or by the public health official, but not by the physician!), evaluated for gonococcal infection, and treated if positive. Alternatively, the physician could provide expedited partner therapy (EPT), especially if the likelihood of follow-up is low.

Intramuscular injection of ceftriaxone is used both for targeted and empirical therapy for gonococcal infection. If chlamydial coinfection is present or has not been ruled out, oral doxycycline is added. If EPT is required, a single dose of oral cefixime can be administered instead of ceftriaxone. If chlamydial infection is present or has not been excluded in the patient's partner, doxycycline (preferred) or azithromycin should be added.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother had ovarian cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (159 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother had ovarian cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (159 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?
hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for a condition that is common in sexually active women < 25 years of age.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation for sexually active women under 25 years of age.

answers.explanation_why: This woman meets the criteria identified by the USPSTF for the screening of a condition that is common among individuals in her age group and should receive testing at this time.

In asymptomatic patients, urine culture is only recommended by the USPSTF for the screening of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant individuals. Asymptomatic bacteriuria does not usually result in symptomatic infection, so the USPSTF recommends against this screening in nonpregnant adults. Screening may result in overtreatment, increasing the risk of patients developing adverse effects from antibiotic therapy and raising the risk of emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

Serum CA-125 concentration can be used in the evaluation of a patient with an adnexal mass or to monitor disease progression or recurrence of treatment in patients with ovarian cancer. Although this patient has a first-degree relative with ovarian cancer, which thereby increases her risk of developing ovarian cancer, serum CA-125 concentration measurement is not recommended for screening of ovarian cancer in asymptomatic patients. Patients with a high-risk family history should rather be referred to genetic counseling.

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening with high-risk HPV testing (hrHPV test) every 5 years in all women > 30 years of age; the American Cancer Society recommends primary HPV testing every 5 years for women 25–65 years of age. In young women, HPV infections tend to be transient and resolve without treatment, and testing in this age group results in a considerable false-positive rate, which can lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, the USPSTF recommends against cervical cancer screening as the harms outweigh the benefits.

answers.content: Perform nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea
answers.explanation_why: The USPSTF recommends screening for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and in women ≥ 25 years of age with specific risk factors (e.g., women with new or multiple sex partners). N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections are often asymptomatic in women but can result in complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease and infertility. Screening consists of nucleic acid amplification tests of the urine, which have both high sensitivity and specificity for these infections. Although there is not a defined screening interval, it is reasonable to annually repeat the screening in women with new or persistent risk factors.

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening by PAP smear every 3 years for all women between 21 and 65 years of age. In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, cervical cancer is rare and screening might result in false-positive results, which may lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). Some of these procedures increase the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm delivery). Because evidence shows that the harms of cervical cancer screening in women younger than 21 years of age outweigh the benefits, the USPSTF recommends against screening in this age group.

question_text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of an itchy and mildly painful rash on her vulva. Her symptoms have progressively worsened despite the use of over-the-counter antihistamines and topical corticosteroid cream. During the past week, she has also had headaches and muscle aches. Medical history is unremarkable. She is sexually active with multiple male partners. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 107/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the genital area is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of an itchy and mildly painful rash on her vulva. Her symptoms have progressively worsened despite the use of over-the-counter antihistamines and topical corticosteroid cream. During the past week, she has also had headaches and muscle aches. Medical history is unremarkable. She is sexually active with multiple male partners. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 107/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. A photograph of the genital area is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The photograph shows fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases in the vulvar and anal areas. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, resulting in erythematous ulcerations.
learning_objective: Recognize genital herpes presentation.

answers.explanation_why: Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, that can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancroid ulcers are typically much larger in size (1–2 cm in diameter) than the small ulcers seen in this patient. Although chancroid ulcers can have an erythematous base, they are usually covered in gray-yellow exudates. In addition, chancroid ulcers are typically extremely painful, whereas this patient has reported only mild pain. Moreover, chancroid is extremely rare in the United States.

images.title: Vaginal ulcer in chancroid
images.description: A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

answers.explanation_why: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that classically manifests with pruritic, planar (flat-topped), polygonal, purple papules and plaques in individuals aged 30–60 years. This condition usually affects the extremities but can also affect the genitals. Although this patient's lesions are mildly pruritic, they do not have the classic morphological features of lichen planus.

images.title: Cutaneous lichen planus
images.description: Scattered, partially coalescent violaceous papules, macules, and plaques are visible on the shins.

answers.explanation_why: Genital herpes, a sexually transmitted infection caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), particularly HSV-2, typically manifests with painful and/or pruritic vesicles in the anogenital region. These vesicles rupture easily, leaving punched out, erythematous ulcerations, as seen here. Primary infection with HSV is usually more severe and lasts longer than recurrent infection, and it often manifests with extragenital findings, including tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, dysuria, fever, and malaise. Although genital herpes is typically self-limited, antiviral drugs (e.g., acyclovir, valacyclovir) diminish the severity and duration of episodes and reduce viral shedding. Recurrence, which is caused by the reactivation of dormant virus in ganglion neurons, is common.

Syphilitic chancres, which are sexually transmitted and caused by Treponema pallidum, typically manifest with a firm ulcer with indurated borders and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, chancres arise as a single painless ulcer rather than multiple painful and pruritic ulcers. Furthermore, the associated lymphadenopathy is usually nontender.

images.title: Chancres on the labium in primary syphilis
images.description: A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.

answers.explanation_why: Lymphogranuloma venereum, a sexually transmitted infection caused by the L1–L3 serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis, can manifest with multiple anogenital ulcers. However, these ulcers are characteristically painless and heal spontaneously within a few days. Lymphogranuloma venereum can cause inguinal lymphadenopathy, but it typically develops weeks after the primary infection.

images.title: Lymphogranuloma venereum
images.description: Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

question_text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of bleeding from a growth in the rectal area. She has also had mild perianal itching and tenderness for the past 2 months. She tried empiric treatment with over-the-counter podofilox solution but reports that “the bumps never completely disappeared.” Her medical history is remarkable for HIV infection and hypertension. She has not been sexually active since her husband died 1 year ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her diet consists mostly of fast food and soft drinks. Current medications include antiretroviral therapy and lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the perianal area shows a 3-cm friable, exophytic mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of bleeding from a growth in the rectal area. She has also had mild perianal itching and tenderness for the past 2 months. She tried empiric treatment with over-the-counter podofilox solution but reports that “the bumps never completely disappeared.” Her medical history is remarkable for HIV infection and hypertension. She has not been sexually active since her husband died 1 year ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Her diet consists mostly of fast food and soft drinks. Current medications include antiretroviral therapy and lisinopril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the perianal area shows a 3-cm friable, exophytic mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's history and examination findings are consistent with refractory anogenital warts.
learning_objective: Recognize refractory anogenital warts in an immunocompromised patient, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why: Intralesional interferon is an immune-mediating therapy that can be used for refractory anogenital warts. It is typically given in conjunction with cytodestructive therapies (e.g., 5-fluorouracil) and/or surgical therapies (e.g., cryoablation). However, a different next step in management is more appropriate prior to the continued treatment of refractory anogenital warts.

Cryoablation is a surgical therapy and one of the first-line treatment options for anogenital warts. However, a different next step in management is more appropriate prior to the continued treatment of refractory anogenital warts.

Chemoradiotherapy (with fluorouracil, mitomycin, and radiation therapy) is the treatment of choice for squamous cell carcinoma of the anal canal. Although malignant degeneration of anogenital warts is more common in immunocompromised patients, and a history of refractory anogenital warts should raise concern for malignancy, the diagnosis should be confirmed prior to initiating treatment.

Anogenital warts turn white upon application of acetic acid. This is, however, a nonspecific finding that is also seen in other conditions such as psoriasis, candidiasis, and lichen planus. Therefore, the application of acetic acid is not recommended in the evaluation of patients with suspected refractory anogenital warts.

A shave biopsy can confirm the diagnosis of anogenital warts and evaluate for malignancy, which is associated with high-risk human papillomavirus types. Findings that should raise concern for malignancy and are indications for biopsy include immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection), insufficient response to treatment, and atypical features (e.g., induration, bleeding, pigmentation, ulceration), all of which are seen here. Evaluation with anoscopy should also be considered to evaluate for involvement within the anal canal.

Recurrence and refractory disease are common in patients with anogenital warts, especially in individuals with immunosuppression. Treatments for anogenital warts include cytodestructive therapies (e.g., trichloroacetic acid), immune-mediated therapies (e.g., imiquimod), and surgical therapies (e.g., cryoablation, excision).

question_text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a genital lesion that she first noticed 3 days ago. There is no pain or pruritus and the patient has had no vaginal discharge. Six months ago, she had a lower urinary tract infection that was treated with oral nitrofurantoin. She is sexually active with a new male partner, whom she met 2 weeks ago. She has an intrauterine device and uses condoms consistently. She has no history of serious illness or allergies and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. A photograph of the vulva is shown. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a genital lesion that she first noticed 3 days ago. There is no pain or pruritus and the patient has had no vaginal discharge. Six months ago, she had a lower urinary tract infection that was treated with oral nitrofurantoin. She is sexually active with a new male partner, whom she met 2 weeks ago. She has an intrauterine device and uses condoms consistently. She has no history of serious illness or allergies and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. A photograph of the vulva is shown. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: A painless, well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesion with indurated borders in a patient with a new sexual partner should raise concern for a chancre.
learning_objective: Recognize a chancre, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Oral azithromycin is the preferred treatment for granuloma inguinale, which can manifest with painless genital ulcers. However, granuloma inguinale ulcers have rolled granulomatous borders, continuously enlarge, bleed easily, and are described as “beefy-red.” In addition, the causal pathogen is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries; granuloma inguinale is uncommon in the US.

images.title: Granuloma inguinale
images.description: Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

answers.explanation_why: Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for chancroid, which can manifest with well-circumscribed genital ulcers. However, patients usually develop painful, erythematous ulcers with a necrotic base and purulent exudate, rather than a single painless ulcer with indurated borders. Additionally, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and abscess formation, which is not seen here.

images.title: Vaginal ulcer in chancroid
images.description: A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

answers.explanation_why: Although consistent use of barrier contraception significantly lowers the risk of infection with syphilis, it can still be transmitted via skin-to-skin contact with an active lesion (e.g., base of the penis, oral cavity). A single dose of intramuscular penicillin G is the first-line treatment for primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis. Doxycycline or ceftriaxone can be administered to patients who are allergic to penicillin. Patients should also be counseled on the risk of a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, which is an acute, self-limiting (< 1 day), systemic reaction to bacterial endotoxins and pyrogens that are released after the initiation of antibiotic therapy.

Oral doxycycline is the preferred treatment for lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which can manifest with painless genital ulcers during the primary phase of infection. However, most affected individuals present with multiple small, herpetiform lesions, rather than a single well-circumscribed ulcer with indurated borders. In addition, LGV is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, which is not seen here.

Oral acyclovir is the preferred treatment for herpes simplex virus infection, which can manifest with genital lesions. However, affected individuals typically present with grouped painful vesicles on an erythematous base, rather than a single painless ulcer with indurated borders.

images.title: Herpes genitalis
images.description: Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patientFluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

images.title: Chancres on the labium in primary syphilis
images.description: A round, ulcerative lesion with well-defined margins and a central induration is visible on the right labium majorum.This finding is consistent with primary syphilitic chancre.
