question_text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonpainful swelling of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years, and he typically drinks two to three beers daily. He has received all scheduled immunizations until the age of 10 years but has not received any immunizations since then. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a nontender, 15-mm ulcer on the soft palate with raised, indurated borders and a shallow nonexudative base. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally but are not tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6500/mm^3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm^3. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the cervical lymph node shows reactive follicular hyperplasia. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonpainful swelling of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years, and he typically drinks two to three beers daily. He has received all scheduled immunizations until the age of 10 years but has not received any immunizations since then. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a nontender, 15-mm ulcer on the soft palate with raised, indurated borders and a shallow nonexudative base. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally but are not tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6500/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the cervical lymph node shows reactive follicular hyperplasia. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: If this patient had a rapid plasma reagin test, it would likely be positive.
learning_objective: Recognize primary syphilis, and choose the most effective measure to prevent sexually transmitted infections during oral sex.

answers.explanation_why: Completing the immunization schedule (via catch-up immunization) protects against vaccine-preventable diseases such as diphtheria and HPV infection. Diphtheria manifests acutely with sore throat, malaise, fever, pseudomembranous pharyngitis, and painful lymphadenopathy. Oral HPV infection manifests with warts or oropharyngeal squamous cell cancer (SCC). Oropharyngeal SCC can result in a nontender ulcerative lesion and painless cervical lymphadenopathy, but there is no evidence of a malignancy on this patient's lymph node biopsy. There is currently no immunization available against this patient's infection.

This patient is at increased risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection (STI) because he has multiple partners. His nontender oral ulcer with raised, indurated borders (chancre) and concomitant nontender lymphadenopathy (due to reactive follicular hyperplasia) is consistent with primary syphilis. The chancre is usually solitary, and develops at the site of inoculation after about 3 weeks. The chancre resolves without scarring after 3–6 weeks regardless of treatment. While primary syphilitic lesions most often occur in the genital region, about 5–10% of cases of primary syphilis are extragenital. Typical localizations are the oral cavity, hands and fingers, or the anus and perianal region, which reflect sexual practices, but chancres can occur wherever the skin has been in contact with Treponema pallidum from infectious sores. The use of a condom during vaginal or anal sex, and a dental dam during oral sex, can protect an individual against STIs by preventing contact with body fluids or an infectious lesion.

Smoking is one of the most important risk factors for head and neck cancers, and a nontender, ulcerative lesion with concomitant nontender cervical lymphadenopathy is also consistent with malignancy. However, fine-needle aspiration cytology shows no signs of malignancy (e.g., keratin pearls in squamous cell carcinoma, the most common mucosal head and neck cancer); reactive follicular hyperplasia suggests another etiology.

Dietary restriction of gluten is used to prevent manifestations of celiac disease (CD), which is caused by a maladaptive immune response to this protein. CD can lead to oral lesions as a result of malabsorption and nutrient deficiency. However, the oral manifestations of CD are poor dentition, atrophic glossitis, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, and cheilitis. The appearance of this patient's oral ulcer, its painless nature, and the concomitant cervical lymphadenopathy are inconsistent with any of the oral manifestations of CD. Moreover, this patient does not have signs typically seen in CD, such as chronic diarrhea, recurrent abdominal pain, and signs of malabsorption such as weight loss, fatigue, or anemia.

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which can cause oral ulceration and lymphadenopathy. However, HSV infection typically causes multiple, shallow ulcers with flat margins, and both the ulcerations and lymphadenopathy would be painful. Furthermore, herpes infections are prone to recurrence even with acyclovir therapy; previous acyclovir therapy would not have prevented a new episode. Acyclovir only decreases the duration and severity of an active episode and reduces viral shedding during the episode.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 28 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have a bump on my anus.” 
History of Present Illness:

3-day history of a painless, solitary lump on his anus
no pruritus or bleeding 

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
mother age 45 years, father age 55 years, brother age 16 years: alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

smokes marijuana occasionally
binge drinking on weekends
sexually active with multiple male partners, uses condoms inconsistently
has not traveled in the past 9 months

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

37.0°C
(98.7°F)

67/min
17/min
110/70 mm Hg
98%
on RA

180 cm
(5 ft 11 in)
75 kg
(165 lb)
23 kg/m^2

Appearance: no acute distress
Skin: shallow, painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders and smooth base on the anus; no other skin lesions or rashes 
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: S_1 and S_2; no murmur or gallop
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated; bilateral nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy
Neurologic: no abnormalities; fully oriented

Which of the following tests is most likely to be positive?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 28 years Gender: M, self-identified Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have a bump on my anus.” History of Present Illness: 3-day history of a painless, solitary lump on his anus no pruritus or bleeding Past Medical History: unremarkable Medications: none Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: mother age 45 years, father age 55 years, brother age 16 years: alive with no chronic conditions Psychosocial History: smokes marijuana occasionally binge drinking on weekends sexually active with multiple male partners, uses condoms inconsistently has not traveled in the past 9 months Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 37.0°C(98.7°F) 67/min 17/min 110/70 mm Hg 98%on RA 180 cm(5 ft 11 in) 75 kg(165 lb) 23 kg/m2 Appearance: no acute distress Skin: shallow, painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders and smooth base on the anus; no other skin lesions or rashes Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: S1 and S2; no murmur or gallop Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated; bilateral nontender inguinal lymphadenopathy Neurologic: no abnormalities; fully oriented Which of the following tests is most likely to be positive?
hint: A solitary, painless, firm ulcer with indurated borders and smooth base is consistent with primary syphilis.
learning_objective: Recognize primary syphilis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study to confirm the diagnosis.

answers.content: Polymerase chain reaction for herpes simplex virus
answers.explanation_why: Polymerase chain reaction for herpes simplex virus is used in the diagnosis of genital herpes, which typically manifests with multiple, grouped, erythematous vesicles that progress to painful ulcers in the anogenital area. This patient has a single, painless ulcer, which is consistent with primary syphilis, not genital herpes.

answers.content: Nucleic acid amplification test for Chlamydia trachomatis
answers.explanation_why: A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) for Chlamydia trachomatis is used in the diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which can manifest with painless anogenital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, while LGV ulcers are typically herpetiform, the presence of indurated borders is most consistent with primary syphilis. Additionally, lymphadenopathy in LGV is typically painful and unilateral.

The Treponema pallidum particle agglutination (TPPA) test is a treponemal test (TT) that detects antibodies against treponemal antigens. Serological syphilis testing algorithms combine TTs and nontreponemal tests (NTTs) to reduce the rate of false-positive results and confirm the diagnosis. The standard algorithm consists of an NTT followed by a TT, whereas the reverse algorithm involves a TT followed by an NTT. If both tests are positive, a current or past T. pallidum infection is likely. False-negative results are possible in early primary syphilis as antibodies do not develop until 1–4 weeks after the ulcer appears. TTs can seroconvert earlier than NTTs, which makes TPPA more likely to yield a positive result in a patient with early syphilis.

Direct detection methods (e.g., dark-field microscopy, direct fluorescent antibody test, PCR) are highly specific diagnostic alternatives. However, these techniques require specialized laboratory equipment, which is often unavailable. T. pallidum cannot be cultivated in vitro or visualized with light microscopy.

images.title: Syphilis serological testing algorithm
images.description:
FTA-ABS: fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption
NTT: nontreponemal test
RPR: rapid plasma reagin
TPPA: treponema pallidum particle agglutination
TT: treponemal test
VDRL: venereal disease research laboratory

answers.explanation_why: Cultures are used to diagnose certain STIs, such as gonorrhea (caused by Neisseria gonorrhea). However, the causative pathogen of syphilis, Treponema pallidum, cannot be cultivated in vitro.

Light microscopy is used in the diagnosis of certain STIs, such as granuloma inguinale (caused by Klebsiella granulomatis), which manifests with painless genital lesions. However, when granuloma inguinale lesions ulcerate, they form large, beefy-red lesions that bleed easily. Additionally, granuloma inguinale lesions are most commonly located on the foreskin, coronal sulcus, or glans. This patient has a single ulcer with no bleeding that is located on the anus, which is more consistent with syphilis, and Treponema pallidum cannot be visualized with light microscopy.

question_text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of a urethral discharge and painful urination. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are metformin and amlodipine. He is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with his wife and does not use condoms. He reports that his wife does not have similar symptoms. He works as a long-haul truck driver. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Genital examination shows purulent discharge from the urethral meatus. There is no scrotal swelling or tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Nucleic acid amplification testing of urethral discharge is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and negative for Chlamydia trachomatis. The results of a screening test for HIV and a rapid plasma reagin test are negative. The physician counsels the patient on the need to return for a follow-up visit and bring his wife into the office for testing. The patient says that it is difficult for them to take time off from work, and they can only come for a visit in several weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of a urethral discharge and painful urination. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His only medications are metformin and amlodipine. He is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with his wife and does not use condoms. He reports that his wife does not have similar symptoms. He works as a long-haul truck driver. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg. Genital examination shows purulent discharge from the urethral meatus. There is no scrotal swelling or tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Nucleic acid amplification testing of urethral discharge is positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and negative for Chlamydia trachomatis. The results of a screening test for HIV and a rapid plasma reagin test are negative. The physician counsels the patient on the need to return for a follow-up visit and bring his wife into the office for testing. The patient says that it is difficult for them to take time off from work, and they can only come for a visit in several weeks. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Expedited partner therapy (EPT) is indicated for certain sexually transmitted infections (STI).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for the sexual partner of a patient with gonorrhea.

answers.content: Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient only
answers.explanation_why: Although intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat gonorrhea, sexual partners, such as this patient's wife, should also receive treatment. EPT is recommended for all sexual partners of the patient from the past 60 days to treat the infection and avoid reinfections.

answers.content: Oral cefixime for the patient and his wife
answers.explanation_why: Although oral cefixime can be used as an alternative regimen to treat individuals with gonorrhea and their sexual partners, this therapy has limited efficacy and should only be considered if first-line treatment is unavailable.

answers.content: Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime for his wife
answers.explanation_why:
A single dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea of the cervix, urethra, rectum, and pharynx in patients in whom concurrent chlamydia infection has been excluded. To prevent reinfections, the CDC recommends that all sexual partners from the past 60 days be evaluated and treated with the same regimen as the patient. If sexual partners cannot be evaluated in a timely manner, EPT with a single dose of oral cefixime is recommended. Oral doxycycline should be added to the treatment if chlamydia infection has not been excluded in the index patient. In addition to EPT, sexual partners should be provided with written information on gonorrhea, its treatment, and adverse effects of medication. They should also be advised to seek medical evaluation if symptoms or adverse events occur.

EPT is legally allowed in most states, although under varying conditions. There is no state that prohibits EPT.

answers.content: Oral doxycycline for the patient and his wife
answers.explanation_why: Oral doxycycline is the first-line treatment for C. trachomatis infection, which can manifest with urethral discharge and dysuria. However, this patient tested positive only for N. gonorrhea, which is not treated with doxycycline.

answers.content: Intramuscular ceftriaxone for the patient and oral cefixime and doxycycline for his wife
answers.explanation_why: Intramuscular ceftriaxone can be used to treat gonorrhea. Dual therapy with both oral cefixime and doxycycline is indicated for sexual partners if coinfection with chlamydia is either suspected or cannot be ruled out in the index patient. However, because the index patient is negative for C. trachomatis, dual therapy is unnecessary.
